Document_Content: urn:contentItem:4638-BNK0-015G-T3JP-00000-00<published>2002-06-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 39</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tanker in fiery end;<br/>3 crew die in crash</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">RENO -- An air tanker crashed after its wings fell off while fighting a forest fire in northern California yesterday, killing the three crew members on board.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Amateur video shot by a passer-by showed both wings tearing away from the plane in mid-air.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The fiery fuselage then rolled and spiralled nose first into the ground, exploding in a ball of flame.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>REUTERS</p></bodyText></section><p>The crash then sparked a new blaze.</p><p> The tanker was battling a 3250ha blaze that had forced 400 people out of their homes in Walker, 150km south of Reno and about 40km north of Yosemite national park.</p><p> Other aircraft battling the fire were grounded.</p><p> A Reno TV station's news crew was interviewing a man watching the skies with his own video recorder when the plane came into view.</p><p> The aircraft was flying low, trailing a red flow of fire retardant above tall green pines. Both wings suddenly snapped off, with flashes of flame as they separated.</p><p> "We saw it circle around once and then drop through the middle there . . . that's where we saw it break up," reporter Terri Russell said.</p><p> Also yesterday, in Colorado, a US federal magistrate ordered a fire prevention officer be held without bail on charges of having ignited the largest bushfire in the state's history.</p><p> Prosecutors argued community anger at the woman could make her a flight risk.</p><p> Federal officials said Terry Barton, 38, confronted with inconsistencies in her statements, admitted starting what has become known as the Hayman fire, 90km southwest of Denver in an abandoned camping ground in the Pike National Forest.</p><p> Ms Barton told investigators she had received a letter from her estranged husband and was so upset she burned it, setting off a conflagration that has consumed some 41,200ha and destroyed 25 homes.</p><p> Barton, a mother of two, entered the federal courtroom in Denver in handcuffs.</p><p> A veteran of more than 18 years with the service, Ms Barton was on patrol June 8 helping enforce a ban on illegal campfires in the bone-dry forest.</p><p> She was charged with three criminal counts: setting fire to timber in a national forest, damaging federal property and making false statements to investigators.</p><p> If convicted of all charges, she faces up to 20 years in prison and up to $1.35 million in fines.</p><p> Firefighters were shocked a colleague could be responsible for such a tragedy.</p><p> "I think accidents do happen and I don't think she meant to start the fire and if she could take that letter back I think that she would," said Oregon firefighter Raymond McIntyre.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4M4B-48B0-TX52-J28N-00000-00Year of the mega fires2006-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisEDPg. 18Year of the mega firesBruce Esplin

IT'S time to rethink our attitude to bushfires. We are now entering one of the most dangerous fire seasons the state has seen.

It is vitally important everyone in Victoria is aware of just how significant their role is.

How we get through this fire season will be measured by how we work together.

This means fire services, public land managers, emergency services, government departments and, most importantly, communities.

It's time to rethink attitudes to bushfire. Not just in Victoria, but in many parts of Australia.

It is no longer relevant to talk about above-average fire seasons.

Victorians must accept that drought and bushfires are the norm, wet years are now the exception.

Fire seasons are starting earlier, lasting longer and include more extreme fire weather days.

American forest fire experts are using the term ''mega fires'' to describe huge fires that are almost impossible to contain; fires such as the one we experienced in 2002-03.

Victorians must consider the notion of mega fires, in particular the American view that we need a greater focus on prevention, mitigation and community engagement.

Firefighters and farmers in communities I've visited have told me they have witnessed fire behaviour they have not experienced before.

Now, more than ever, is the time for communities to plan, prepare and equip themselves to play their part in increasing bushfire safety.

The fire services have made significant improvements to capability and procedures to ensure they can play their part. Individuals in high fire-risk areas must do the same.

This fire season has been likened to the conditions of Ash Wednesday; prolonged drought, increased temperatures and an early start to

the summer.

However the similarities end there. Our fire services work together better, are better equipped and have significant air attack capability.

Most importantly, many community members are well prepared to play their role.

But there is no room for complacency. We have already seen reports of farmers selling up and walking off the land.

This is a family tragedy and can have substantial impact on the local economy.

These people are CFA volunteers, SES volunteers and Rural Ambulance volunteers.

Their wives are the backbone of the Red Cross and the Country Women's Association.

We should not lose sight that many Victorian communities are undeniably stressed by 10 years of drought conditions, by major fires in 2002-03 and again in the summer of 2006.

Many people are still recovering from last summer's fires and must now face forecasts of an even worse fire season.

Melburnians can help their rural Victorian neighbours through tourism and by putting their money into areas where farmers are struggling.

As they did last summer, groups such as Rotary, Lions and the Council of Churches will come to the aid of people affected by fires by offering assistance in mending fences, helping with agistment and sourcing fodder. But we can all do more.

Since the Victorian Bushfire Inquiry in 2003, nearly $200 million has been provided to strengthen fire management, with more announced this week focusing on isolated rural communities.

Community education programs have been bought forward and planning is well advanced.

Fire cover can be maintained for the whole of the state, including a ''surge capacity'' to ensure new fires can be attacked quickly and aggressively.

Bushfire preparedness is not something we do for the bad years, it is something we must do all year and every year.

BRUCE ESPLIN is Emergency Services Commissioner for Victoria

urn:contentItem:5HW6-07H1-JD3N-5356-00000-00Welcome mat out in Birregurra2016-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Welcome mat out in BirregurraErin PEARSON

TUCKED away out the back of Birregurra a pop-up com-munity is in full swing. Set up to house and feed more than 220 firefighters who arrived almost overnight, the tent city has taken over the football ground and is filled with men and women who are here to battle the blaze that continues to burn deep in the dense Otway bush.

The camp has the small community of Birregurra abuzz with activity as dozens of Geelong and Surf Coast businesses are called in to service the firefighters.

This week, site manager Rodney Croft gave the Geelong Advertiser a tour of base camp.

"We've got about 220 -staying here and that's been pretty constant for the last few weeks. A mix of night sleepers and day sleepers," he said.

"We've got resources out on the line all the time doing 13 to 14-hour shifts each day.

"Many are awake by 5am and ready to hit the showers." Lightning strikes are -believed to have sparked the blaze on December 19 before extreme heat and wind flared the fire on Christmas Day.

Since then the Jamieson Track fire has burnt about 2500ha, destroyed 116 homes and impacted the townships of Wye River and Separation Creek.

And while the Great Ocean Road has reopened, advice messages remain in place for Lorne, Wye River, Separation Creek, Allenvale, Grey River, Sugarloaf and Wongarra.

Mr Croft's job is to make sure the needs of those calling the campsite home are met.

There's a mix of paid staff and volunteers from the New Zealand forest fire team, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Parks Victoria, the SES and contract companies.

The task is enormous: they go through 750 lunches every two days, 10,000 litres of diesel and close to 100 portable air-conditioners are hooked up to help reduce the threat of fatigue.

"The chefs from Andrew Crawford catering are given 24 to 48 hours notice of -deployment as part of their contract," Mr Croft said.

"They're now sending out 750 lunch packs every two days and on Wednesday, due to the shocking conditions, they even delivered the meals straight out to the frontline.

"The guys here must eat a certain amount of kilojoules each day, a mixture of chicken, steak and more.

"They're averaging up to 7000kj per day, the equivalent to that of a marathon runner." On Thursday night the menu boasted roast lamb and chicken pie, Friday night shepherd's pie before chocolate rice pudding, muffin bread and butter pudding.

"It's all about fatigue -management, that's a high priority for us, so they all get the same amount of care.

"It's basically their home away from home. It's the best part of glorified camping." On Wednesday afternoon, with strong winds predicted, a local bus company got the call to send in almost a dozen big buses.

"We knew there would be high winds so we used them for windbreaks. We called up to see if they could help and we had them within half an hour," Mr Croft said.

"And when dry lightning strikes hit, we pulled guys out of tents because of the aluminium poles - the lightning came right through here. We had 79 tents lost in the storm that came through that night." To the east of the oval campsite are portable shower blocks built in shipping containers from Altona, to the west are specialist dark tents nicknamed igloos -imported from the US to -enable the -"day sleepers" to rest in air-conditioned tents set at 20C.

Women have their own dark tents and emergency sleeping areas. Mr Croft, who's latest base camp management roll is his seventh, said up to 15 per cent of the workforce were female, a number that has increased every year since he joined DELWP a decade ago.

Next door a small weatherboard house is surrounded by sheep. "A widow of 90 years lives over the back fence there. She's been pretty happy with the company," Mr Croft laughed.

As for the Birregurra cricket and football teams, they needn't worry. Organisers have assured them the ground will be returned in better condition than when they arrived.

There is one agreement they must stick to though - no tents on the centre square.

"The local cricket team is still allowed on site to train in the cricket nets and it will all be redressed before we leave. The entire centre square though, that's flagged off as part of the agreement.

"As to how long we'll be here for, it depends on how we go with the fire fight." On Thursday, fresh faces arrived in the form of the Port Phillip fire crew, comprising men and women from Parks Victoria and DELWP. They sat waiting in the footy boxes for their next -instruction, sipping coffee as they contemplated the days ahead.

The young fireys received the call-up only two days -earlier, but most said they had done this many times before.

Andrew Wyver from Knox said the Birregurra base camp was an impressive set-up. "It's always interesting being with crews from around the area," he said. "This here, this is what we do, it's the main role of our team." This month 44 New Zealand firefighters joined forces with Australian crews to tackle the Jamieson Track bushfire.

Led by field-based liaison -officers Scott Marchant and Graeme Still, two teams - Alpha and Bravo - have been mixed with DELWP -seasonal firefighters on the fire ground and at base camp.

"The best thing that has happened is that we have integrated between the Kiwis and the Kangaroos well and we have made sure we have a mixed team on the fire ground," Mr Still said.

"Everyone has gotten on so well and already exchanging email addresses and Facebook.

"When the time comes to work hard we come together and get the job done." For many of the crew this is a return deployment having helped Victoria with previous fires. For Mr Still, this is his fifth visit.

"The guys selected to come over here are very experienced, arduous firefighters and are used to this type of work in dense forested areas. Nothing fazes us," he said. "The locals have treated us so well it is sometimes overwhelming." A short stroll down the road is Birregurra's main street.

Royal Mail Hotel owner Ambrose Wilkins said the pub had put on extra staff to cater for the demand from fireys in search of a wind down drink at night. The weekly meal turn over has also skyrocketed to 800 plates a week, only nine weeks after his young family took over the pub.

"They're tired, they're exhausted and all they want to do is relax and this is the perfect place," Mr Wilkins said.

"They come in smelling like smoke but they're so friendly. We've met people from all around the state.

"We're having up to 60 people a night and on New Year's Eve we would have had more than 100." For Mr Croft though, life on the frontline is all in a day's work. He's next task for the day is to meet the SES volunteers manning the front gate whose job it is to check in and out all vehicles involved in the firefighting mission.

"They make sure people come back," Mr Croft said.

"Essentially we're here to support the firefighters, however long it goes. "You've always got to be ahead of the game and prepared for anything."

QUICK FACTS â–  14-hour work days â–  5250 meals cooked per week â–  220 firefighting crew from Australia and New Zealand camping in tentsâ–  10,000 litres of diesel.

urn:contentItem:4M05-FGK0-TX52-F1YY-00000-00Australia urged to step in as China stokes illegal logging2006-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisWORLD TABLEPg. 8

MATP

Australia urged to step in as China stokes illegal loggingGreg Roberts

THREE out of four logs exported from Papua New Guinea and Indonesia are felled illegally and developed countries such as Australia should do more to stop importing them, says a new report by the World Bank on the forestry industry.

The report by the bank's environment and rural development departments singles out China for encouraging illegal logging to supply its booming industry in finished timber products.

The report says illegal logging worldwide is causing losses of assets and revenue in excess of $US10 billion ($13 billion) annually -- more than six times the amount governments spend on forestry management.

Governments are losing a further $6.4 billion a year in evaded taxes and royalties through illegal logging.

''Large-scale operators continue with impunity,'' says the report, Strengthening Forest Law Enforcement and Governance.

''Arguably, this is the worst form of violation of equity of justice, arising from a clear failure of governance and it needs to be addressed.''

The World Bank findings contradict a report prepared recently by Australian consultancy ITS Global for Malaysian forestry giant Rimbunan Hijau, the main logging operator in Papua New Guinea.

The Rimbunan Hijau report says that after ''exhaustive analysis'', ITS Global consultants had concluded that claims that most logging in PNG was illegal were baseless, and that any ''irregularities'' in the industry had been corrected.

The World Bank report says an estimated 70 per cent of total logging production in PNG is illegal, a proportion exceeded by only four other nations including Indonesia, where between 70 and 80 per cent of logging is illegal.

The report says consumer countries should do more to reduce the motive for illegal logging by reforming markets.

The Australian Government is examining ways of banning imports of illegally sourced timber from PNG and Indonesia, but Canberra has pointed out the difficulties raised by the exporting of illicit logs to countries such as China, from where timber products are in turn exported.

The World Bank said the value of wood imports into China had increased from $7.7billion in 1996 to $20.5billion in 2005 to meet increased demand for export products such as furniture and wood-based panelling.

The Chinese did not distinguish between legally and illegally produced timber for imports from PNG, Indonesia and other countries.

''It is feared that the Chinese demand is escalating the problem of illegal logging in several producer countries that are characterised by weak forest law enforcement and governance.''

The report says legal log harvesting accounted for just 17million cubic metres of Indonesia's annual production of 74million cubic metres.

This was because most commercially viable timber from legal forest concessions had been exhausted and plantations had not been developed quickly enough to meet the shortfall.

Indonesia and Brazil had experienced repeated and costly episodes of uncontrolled forest fire due to the ''gross violation of standards and regulations''.

The report says that 350 million people were heavily dependent on forests for their livelihoods and a further one billion were partly dependent.

THE BIG CHOP

Top 10 illegal logging nations.

Estimated portion of total timber production from illegal logging.

* Cambodia .... 90 per cent

* Bolivia .... 80 per cent

* Peru .... 80 per cent

* Indonesia .... 70-80 per cent

* Papua New Guinea ... 70 per cent

* Ecuador .... 70 per cent

* Gabon .... 70 per cent

* Ghana .... 60 per cent

* Cameroon .... 50 per cent

* Laos .... 45 per cent

Sources: Savcor Indufor Oy, Food and Agriculture Organisation, European Forest Institute, World Bank.

urn:contentItem:4B4D-DPT0-01S8-83X3-00000-00<published>1993-11-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Backpack kill link</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>WARREN OWENS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SYDNEY: Homicide detectives are reinvestigating the killing of a young woman hitchhiker in a bid to determine whether she may have been the Belanglo serial killer's eighth victim - and the first dumped outside that notorious forest.<br/>Backpacker murder squad police are reviewing the case of Dianne Pennacchio, found stabbed to death in a State forest almost 200km south of the Belanglo forest "graveyard".<br/>Detectives say the murder of the young Queanbeyan mother in September, 1991, involved similar elements to many of the Belanglo forest killings.</p><p>Two detectives from Task Force Air have spent the past week in Queanbeyan studying evidence from the Pennacchio case, the first non-Belanglo murder confirmed under active investigation by the elite squad.<br/>Mrs Pennacchio, 29, was last seen late at night leaving a hotel at Bungendore, east of Canberra, to hitch a ride home to nearby Queanbeyan. She never arrived.<br/>Her body was found two months later in the Tallanganda State Forest, south of the Bungendore-Queanbeyan road.<br/>Two forestry workers found the body face down, hidden alongside a log and covered with pine needles about 10m from a forest fire trail.<br/>Virtually all the Belanglo forest victims have been found in almost identical bushland settings.<br/>Task Force Air commander Superintendent Clive Small said earlier that the similarity of the Belanglo body sites could well mark the "signature" of a serial killer.<br/>He said specialist officers would analyse the detailed findings so far, but suggested a pattern might be emerging from the nature and location of the death scenes.<br/>"All we can do is follow the perimeter of the pine forest where we have found the bodies near all the fire trails," he said.<br/>Mrs Pennacchio was savagely stabbed to death, as most of the Belanglo victims were believed to have died.<br/>Police also say she was probably killed elsewhere and dumped at the forest site.<br/>Police said numerous other crime scenes have been visited by the squad's 35 detectives, but police have refused to name individual cases.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4591-NSJ0-0197-846C-00000-00<published>1999-10-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. T08</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>TEEN REACHES FOR THE SKY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>VICKY ROACH</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">October Sky (PG)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Director: Joe Johnston</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Starring: Jake Gyllenhaal, Chris Cooper, Natalie Canerday, Chris Owen and Laura Dern</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Screening: Greater Union City and suburbs</p><p nitf:lede="true"> * * *   1/2</p><p nitf:lede="true">In 1957 there were only two ways out of Coalwood, West Virginia: on a football scholarship or in a coffin. So weedy Homer Hickam did, in fact, have to be a rocket scientist in order to cheat his dust-eating destiny.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The NASA science engineer was headed for the coal mines like his father before him until a glimpse of the Soviet satellite Sputnik changed his life. So the 17-year-old dreamer decided to shoot for the stars. And owing to a potent combination of inspiration and perspiration, he actually got damn close …</p><p>If it weren't based on a true story, October Sky would be a bit too corny to be convincing. As director Joe Johnston (Jumanji) puts it: "[Hickam's story] involves themes that are so universal to the experience of coming-of-age in 20th century America that it approaches the status of a modern fable."</p><p> Homer Hickam, played in the film by City Slickers' Jake Gyllenhaal, is too small to earn a football scholarship like his older brother, a handsome high school jock.</p><p> His domineering dad (Chris Cooper) has plans for Homer to follow him down the mine -- represented in the film as a belching monster that periodically spits out injured or dead.</p><p> But Homer has other ideas. After seeing Sputnik in the October sky, he decides to build his own rocket with the help of three school friends (William Lee Scott, Chad Lindberg and Chris Owen).</p><p> When the prototype blows up his mother's picket fence, Homer's dad banishes his rocket-making activities. So Homer trudges 13km out of town to build his very own "Cape Coalwood".</p><p> When a rocket is accused of starting a forest fire, Homer swots up on advanced mathematics to prove the boys' innocence. Even a night in jail isn't enough to stop this young achiever for long.</p><p> Despite some dangerously close calls, the initially sceptical townsfolk get behind the Rocket Boys, as Hickam's autobiography is titled. Encouraged by a supportive teacher (Laura Dern), they enter the annual science fair -- which ultimately provides their ticket out of town and into college.</p><p> There's a simple, almost nostalgic innocence to October Sky. A stirring Boys Own adventure about a young man who had the courage -- and tenacity -- to successfully pursue his dream.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4KBF-VW30-TX52-M1SJ-00000-00DOOM & GLOOM2006-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10DOOM & GLOOM

EIGHT BODIES FOUND IN CARS

BRAZILIAN police found eight bodies in two abandoned cars on the outskirts of Rio de Janeiro yesterday.

The bodies of people aged 20-25 show signs of torture and bullet wounds typical of executions. ''They are drug traffickers involved in a turf war,'' Rio Police Sergeant Luis Bensaba said. Police believe the slain belong to a gang from the Monkeys' Hill slum, which has been fighting a rival group from the Sao Joao slum over drugs sales.

RUSSIAN TROOPS ATTACKED

SEVEN Russian troops were killed and 25 wounded yesterday when gunmen attacked their military column in Chechnya, Interfax news agency reported.

Sources said the column was southeast of Grozny.

Rebel attacks are frequent and police and soldiers die every week. In recent years, the separatist war in Chechnya has evolved into a general Islamist uprising.

HAND CART BOMB INJURES 10

A BOMB hidden in a cart exploded today in a crowded intersection of downtown Kabul, injuring 10 people.

And five Afghan labourers were ambushed and fatally shot on their way to a US military base in east Afghanistan.

The attacks come amid an upsurge of violence by Taliban-led rebels, 12 of whom were killed.

The bomb had been planted in a hand cart behind a car, police official Mohammed Nabi said. The explosion took place at a busy intersection near the presidential palace.

SECOND HIGH PROFILE ABDUCTION

AN Iraqi deputy minister and his 19 bodyguards were kidnapped by gunmen in broad daylight today and held for 10 hours before being released.

The US military said today it killed an al-Qaida operative suspected of bombing a Baghdad market last week that left 66 people dead.

Deputy Electricity Minister Raad al-Hareth and his bodyguards were in four cars when they were ambushed by gunmen wearing uniforms in Talbiyah, an official said.

TOWN FORCED TO FLEE FIRE

ABOUT 4000 people were yesterday forced to flee a raging forest fire that threatened to cut off their only escape from a small mining town in western Canada.

Residents of Tumbler Ridge in British Columbia were ordered to leave as the blaze burned to within 12km, provincial fire department spokeswoman Radha Fisher said.

Most headed to two nearby towns, she said.

''The fire raced almost 16km in just four hours,'' Fisher said. ''It was originally caused by lightning. The reason it's now so big is that conditions are dry.''

DUBLIN AIRPORT BOMB SCARE

POLICE ordered the emergency evacuation of Dublin International Airport yesterday after a man claiming to have a bomb in a suitcase was arrested in the arrivals hall.

Ireland's national police force, the Garda Siochana, said several units and the Irish army bomb squad were sent to the airport, 15km north of central Dublin.

No explosive device was found.

Dublin Airport Authority spokeswoman Siobhan Moore said all travellers and staff had been evacuated.

MOTHER, CHILD STARVE TO DEATH

A MOTHER and her five-year-old daughter starved to death in the suburbs of Paris and their bodies lay undiscovered in an apartment for up to four months, police said today.

The mother was named as Doomitra, 32, from Mauritius, and the child was called Chana.

''The post-mortem showed it was a natural death and not a murder or intoxication. They died three or four months ago,'' a police official said, adding the mother must have prevented her daughter from eating.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H3J0-TXN5-R166-00000-00Give it dry food, wind and a monster is born2001-12-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 6Give it dry food, wind and a monster is bornDANGEROUS BEHAVIOUR BUSHFIRES THE STATE ABLAZECynthia Banham

The four factors that affect the behaviour of a bushfire, according to the CSIRO's Phil Cheney, are the amount of fuel, moisture content, wind speed and slope.

A principal scientist in bushfire research and management, Mr Cheney says bushfires start in a number of ways, by lightning strikes or spontaneous combustion, but much more commonly by people or man-made contraptions like powerlines.

Once lit, how quickly the fire spreads and how difficult it is to contain is determined first by how much fuel such as dead grass, litter and debris is lying around. Mr Cheney then says a combination of how much moisture in the fuel which depends on the temperature and humidity on the day and wind is responsible for about 80per cent of the speed of a blaze.

The impact of the wind depends on whether the fire is in open grassland or forest.

"Once you get up above 10 or 15kph, if you double the wind speed you double the rate of spread. In open grasslands we can say we'd expect roughly the fire will spread at about half the average wind speed, and about a quarter of the average wind speed in forests," he said.

A further decider of bushfire behaviour is the slope of the land. Fire spreads faster up the slope in the direction of the wind because the flames are leaning into the fuel.

While grass fires spread faster, Mr Cheney says they are easier to put out than forest fires. Firefighters approach grass fires from the back of the fire on the upward side, working along the flanks of the fire.

"If we can't catch up with the head of the fire we just have to keep working until the conditions ease. That's usually at night, when the wind drops and the humidity rises," he says.

In a forest fire access is more difficult and firefighters usually have to wait until it reaches a road. When conditions ease, bulldozers are used to carve a trail in the forest to create a bare piece of ground. Firefighters either use water from a tanker, knapsack or aircraft to battle the blaze.

The bush is so combustible because it has evolved over millions of years so that fire has become an integral part of it, says the director-general of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, Brian Gilligan.

It has a high content of eucalyptus and tea-tree oil and many plants depend on fire to reproduce, with the heat cracking open seed pods and stimulating the germination cycle.

urn:contentItem:7X0J-7T70-YB64-44H0-00000-00Unlocking the impenetrable2009-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisEXTRABooksPg. 12Unlocking the impenetrableNicole Trian

Wonders of a Godless World

Andrew McGahan

(Allen & Unwin, $32.99)

Reviewed by Nicole Trian

THIS is a dark and forbidding book that proved difficult to pin down. A winner of the prestigious Miles Franklin literary award for The White Earth and the Vogel literary award for his commercially popular debut, Praise, Andrew McGahan's latest work is an ambitious piece.

There are supernatural forces at play here and while not quite a classic dystopian-style thriller, it nonetheless belongs to that genre, throwing up unknowns like who are these characters, really? What are they trying to achieve? What's behind the phenomena? At times it felt unwieldy. Admittedly, even the expectation of uncovering these mysteries left me ambivalent.

Set on an unnamed island, the plot involves a group of patients confined to the back wards of a ramshackle hospital. Inside, an orphan goes about her work cleaning the wards and helping nurses with their patients. Intellectually impaired, she can't speak, read or write and is largely ignored. Her only gift is for secretly intuiting changes in the weather.

When the arrival of an unidentified man coincides with the eruption of a nearby volcano, strange things begin to happen. The "foreigner" is in a coma yet he begins to speak to the orphan. His voice reaches her telepathically. He not only reads her thoughts but he enters the minds of other patients and staff. What we know of him comes from the fantastical stories he tells of having died and been reborn many times over. How he'd defied the world's worst natural disasters â€“ landslide, forest fire, tsunami â€“ and even survived starvation while living as a prophet in a religious compound.

The foreigner delights in teaching the orphan the mechanics of nature; the unseen forces that whip up squally winds, rain, fires and storms and cause volcanoes to erupt. The facts are no doubt interesting but the explanations are unnecessarily long.

It's this emphasis, however, on cataclysmic events and life after death that points to more penetrating issues.

McGahan has tapped into what are arguably two of the most controversial and polarising debates of contemporary culture: environmentalism and the nature of consciousness.

Both debates have bred experts and gurus (specifically the self-help industry) and alongside the genuine science produced some spurious claims, so it's no surprise McGahan has chosen characters damaged by madness as conduits for raising questions about humanity's place in the world.

It's a complex and challenging treatment. Furthermore, it's not until halfway into the book that these ideas clearly emerge.

Like the foreigner, the orphan is trapped in her own world. His stories are her only escape: "Only you my orphan can appreciate what I was going through ... the desolation of being utterly different from every other being around you." He awakens in her the possibility of another life conceiving of the "wonders" of the world beyond her dull, anonymous existence. Through him she flies away from the island, mines the bowels of the earth and catapults herself into space, and she experiences for the first time the pleasures of the flesh.

More importantly, the orphan discovers that while life and death are seemingly random, there are unseen laws governing the natural world. As the foreigner explains "the earth only destroys in a way that provides for life in the longer term".

Embedded in the foreigner's stories of natural disasters and the scale of the devastation are dire warnings about humanity's responsibility for the state of our planet. Tied in with this are questions McGahan raises about the way in which our thoughts can consciously and subconsciously create our reality.

Whatever the unknown consequences, choices need to be made. And McGahan has made some brave ones. Much of the story is told as a telepathic dialogue between the foreigner and orphan, and navigating its layers of abstraction requires a degree of perseverance. There's a risk of getting lost in all the profundity or, worse, simply giving up trying.

urn:contentItem:49K3-7N90-01S8-D1VN-00000-00<published>1987-11-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GOLD TV GUIDE; Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>MONDAY For Those I Loved, (four-part mini-series), 8.30 pm, Channel;<br/> York and York . . . yawn</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>FINCKE M</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FUTURE producers take note: if you ever sign a "big star" to your mini-series, don't be wasteful. Give him/her at least two parts.</p><p>Take For Those I Loved, for example. Michael York gets to play not only the hero Martin Gray, but Martin's father as well. A rumor that he was to play Martin's mother but the dress was too small, is completely unfounded.</p><p> Martin is a lucky man. He has a beautiful wife, four delightful children and the happiest homelife since The Waltons. But, as is wont in an eight-hour mini-series, tragedy strikes and his entire family appears to die in a forest fire.</p><p> Worse still, a crazed if extremely articulate anti-Semite telephones the family home (it survived, the family did not) and tells grief-stricken Martin that the fire should have killed him, and taunts him for being alive.</p><p> In despair, Martin loads up the double-barrelled shotgun to do away with himself, reconsiders, and finally decides to tell the story of his interesting life, as his family would have wanted.</p><p> He trudges (far too slowly) back through his past as a young Jew who turns to black marketeering in Nazi-occupied Warsaw.</p><p> For Those I Loved's Warsaw ghetto roundly deserves an award for Tidiest Wartime Town. The streets are remarkably clean, as are all uniforms. Its German soldiers, predictably, are all stupid, violent, grimacing, goose-stepping thugs who roll their Rs ven zay say her-r-r-ring.</p><p> Vaguely interesting as this series might be during the summer television drought, For Those I Loved is about six hours too long, sustained by a poor script and some less than satisfying acting performances.If only York could have played every part! MICHELLE FINCKE</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4JTH-NG60-TX4S-M23H-00000-00GHD continues to play part in shaping the nation's capital2006-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisAPg. 18GHD continues to play part in shaping the nation's capitalRobert KnottOperating Centre Manager, Canberra

GHD occupies a special place in Canberra's history.

While our office opened here in 1966, our relationship with Australia's capital dates back to the years when the first elements of this planned modern city began to take shape.

One of GHD's founding members, Gordon Gutteridge, served in Canberra in 1928 as Commonwealth Director of Public Health Engineering, and from 1962 to 1968 another of our founders, Geoffrey Davey, served on the National Planning Committee.

This pivotal body reviewed the proposals of the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC), which was the organisation responsible for the realisation of the Canberra we know today.

Over the 40 years to 2006, GHD has continued to lead the management, planning and design of infrastructure and building projects throughout Canberra and surrounding New South Wales.

In the first 20 years, GHD played a key role in the creation of the town centres of Woden, Tuggeranong and Belconnen and the urban development of more than 10,000 residential blocks throughout many of the city's suburbs. The acquisition in 1979 of local consultancy, DJ Dwyer & Associates, consolidated operations, and over the past two decades GHD has continued to diversify to provide integrated, sustainable solutions - not only to the local challenges presented by a maturing city, but also in the provision of professional services to support the national and international operations of the Australian Government.

The company's success in Canberra is the result of the consistent outstanding performance by our people and the continued support of our clients.

The acquisition of Works Australia and forestry consultants RL Newman in 1997, building services firm Lindquist Johnson in 2001, and specialist forest fire consultants Metis Associates in 2005, have also provided a catalyst for continued growth.

Today, GHD in Canberra is 130-people strong and contributes almost $20 million per annum to the local economy. Our professional capabilities span project management, architecture and interior design, building services, engineering, management consulting, and environmental, forestry, training and security services.

GHD's highly skilled professionals are helping to lead major projects in international markets. For example, concept architect, Andrew Raszewski, has designed the Fortune Technology Centre urban precinct in Beijing, project manager, Tony Ryan, is leading the delivery of the Rhaj Gardens development in Abu Dhabi, and the forestry team is providing specialist advice to industry in Indonesia and Malaysia.

GHD's commitment to overseas development assistance is evidenced by senior Canberra-based staff who played a critical role in providing aid relief for the communities that were devastated by the 2004 Boxing Day tsunami. Grahame Crookham led a team that reviewed and recommended the steps needed to reinstate the schools infrastructure in the Maldives, and David Buckley and Gavin Morrison helped last year to deliver vital water and sanitation engineering services in Sri Lanka.

Senior project manager Garth Chamberlain has recently relocated to Aceh to manage Phase 2 of the reconstruction.

GHD remains committed to serving clients locally. Last year GHD opened an office in Nowra and this month it has opened an office in Wagga Wagga.

GHD in Canberra, like its sibling offices throughout the world, will continue to evolve and grow throughout the next 40 years.

GHD will consolidate its success by always remembering that, through the excellence of their people and their performance, they exist to serve clients.

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NK20-TXN5-S06G-00000-00Flood of money lights up sales1999-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 7Flood of money lights up salesTONY BOURKE

SYDNEY

Not even an hour-long power blackout could slow the flood of money that produced record results on the first day of the Sydney Easter yearling sales yesterday.

In recent weeks, all the stock market indicators had signalled a bloodstock boom in the offing and it erupted with the intensity of a forest fire.

There was no early smoke warning, with the first three yearlings offered all soaring past $100,000.

Top price for the session was $800,000, paid by Hong Kong-based trainer Patrick Biancone for a bay colt by Danehill from Princess Tracy, the dam of six winners including the two-year-old colt Cullen, who was sold for $680,000 at last year's sale.

The $800,000 equalled the top price over the three days last year.

Although he did not bring top price, clearly the show-stopper yesterday was the only yearling by the legendary stallion Nureyev ever likely to be offered in Australia. Described by many of the bloodstock experts as a "steal" at $700,000, the bay colt out of the United States-bred mare Miss Bold Appeal - and offered by the Victorian-based Roselands Stud - was bought by English bloodstock agents Andrew Mead and Marian Goodbody on behalf of a London-based group, Alydar International.

Coincidentally, considering the company name of the new owners, the sale of the Nureyev colt, with an opening bid of $500,000, bore some resemblance to the sale of the first Alydar yearling in Australia in 1989. Out of the champion mare Rose Of Kingston, that colt was knocked down to the opening bid of $1million by the late Tommy Smith but he never reached a racetrack. He was later gelded, resold for $1000 and became a champion show horse.

Mead and Goodbody said that if the Nureyev colt had been offered at the major yearling sales in the US or in England, the bidding would have opened at $1million. "We couldn't believe we could get him so cheaply," Mead said.

The colt will race in Australia before eventually going to stud here or overseas, but a trainer has not yet been chosen.

Canberra trainer John Morrisey burst on the scene, paying $650,000 for a bay colt by Danehill from the Zabeel mare Peruzzi, a three-quarter sister-in-blood to the former champion Octagonal and Mouawad.

All up yesterday, 170 lots were sold for an aggregate of $22,176,000 at a record average of $130,447, which easily topped last year's first-day average of $103,132.

20,000</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>AAPINTNEWS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">China blaze threatens 20,000 PEKING._ China's worst forest fire in memory has turned its fury south and now threatens a town of 20,000 people in Inner Mongolia, the official media said yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The New China News Agency said the western sector of the fire was approaching the town of Mangui on the edge of huge virgin forests.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>It said thousands of firefighters were hacking a firebreak 120 kilometres long and 200 metres wide to stop the blaze from reaching Mangui, home to China's only reindeer farm and to a major reserve for rare wild animals.</p><p>The fire has killed more than 200 people, made 50,000 homeless and devastated 600,000 hectares in the northeast province of Heilongjiang.</p><p>Mangui is about 120 kilometres from the town of Uma on the Ergun River, which forms part of China's border with the Soviet Union.</p><p>Forests near Uma are threatened by a fire that has been blazing for a month in the Soviet Union and has reached the Ergun, the People's Daily said.</p><p>It said that a strong wind could carry the fire across the Ergun, which is 150 metres wide at that point.</p><p>State radio said in its morning news bulletin a special State Council (cabinet) group which had taken charge of fire-fighting called for all possible measures to stop the fire spreading to the forests of Inner Mongolia.</p><p>The group has ordered 19 forest farms in the region to create firebreaks and said sufficient equipment must be made available to fight the blaze.</p><p>It also called for firebreaks to be widened in the eastern sector of the blaze where it appears to have been brought under control, and for firefighters there to remain vigilant.</p><p>The People's Daily said the regional government of Inner Mongolia had sent thousands of people to fight the fire.</p><p>Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459J-DXP0-0197-T0CG-00000-00<published>1996-05-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Unions defy call not to strike A 24-HOUR national strike would go ahead in South Africa as planned today, labour boss Sam Shilowa said yesterday. Business and industry leaders and opposition politicians have condemned the strike. The 1.3 million-member Congress of South African Trade Unions has called the strike to protest against plans to introduce a lockout clause in the country's new constitution.</p><p>Troops kill 19 in jailbreak RWANDAN troops killed 19 men in a north-western village in a shoot-out after a prison escape in which an army guard was shot dead, a government spokesman said yesterday. The guard was killed by suspected Hutu infiltrators who attacked the area to free the prisoners. Eight prisoners who escaped were shot dead. The UN Human Rights Office in Rwanda put the death toll higher, at between 25 and 30.</p><p>Fire rages but nuclear lab is safe A FOREST fire raging around a federal nuclear weapons laboratory in the south-west American state of New Mexico poses no immediate danger to the facility. Los Alamos National Laboratory spokesman John Gustafson said the fire's nearest point to the laboratory boundary was several kilometres away.</p><p>Pomp for Suharto wife's funeral TIEN Suharto, the late wife of Indonesian President Suharto, was buried yesterday with state pomp at her family mausoleum at the foot of Mount Lawu near Jakarta. Tien Suharto, 72, who died of a heart attack, was given state honours in a ceremony that included a salvo fired by soldiers of the Kopassus special forces, which one of her sons-in-law leads.</p><p>CIA official blames Iran for crash A SENIOR CIA official has said Iran, not Libya, was behind the December 1988 bombing of an American jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, the German weekly Focus reported. The official, speaking anonymously, said the bomb attack that killed 270 on the Pan American flight was orchestrated by Iran and carried out by Palestinian extremists to avenge the accidental shooting-down of an Iranian airliner by US forces in the Gulf. In Washington, another US intelligence official denied any evidence of Iranian involvement.</p><p>"There is a long and continuing effort by Libya to place the blame somewhere else," the official said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:54B8-4X21-JCM0-6036-00000-00Rain could help damp down WA bushfires2011-11-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisRain could help damp down WA bushfires

Fire crews in Western Australia are hoping some light rain forecast today will help them extinguish a bushfire that has damaged or destroyed more than 30 properties.

More than 400 firefighters have spent the night working to contain the fire near Margaret River.

The Department of Environment and Conservation has re-issued an emergency warning for much of the area but is hoping cooler temperatures and lighter winds will help them shore up containment lines.

Western Power says 500 homes are without power as the fire continues to move south.

The utility provider says huge generators have been moved to the outskirts of Margaret River and crews are waiting for approval from firefighters to move in and set them up.

Locals who were forced to flee the tiny coastal community of Prevelly on jet skis yesterday described how they huddled for shelter under a jetty as the fire raged on sand dunes behind them.

The fire has so far damaged or destroyed 34 properties, including the historic Wallcliffe House.

Firefighters are also working to tackle two fires which are burning near Denmark on Western Australia's south coast.

The Margaret River fire was sparked on Wednesday when embers from a controlled burn jumped a containment line.

Strong winds yesterday buffeted the fire and pushed its southern front into the beachside communities of Prevelly and Gnarabup.

The Bureau of Meteorology is predicting drizzle for the early morning with westerly winds at 10 kilometres per hour, down from 50kph yesterday.

"The fire is what we would call contained. It's relatively secure but we've still got in the southern part of the fire quite a bit of work to do to make it secure and to mop it up," incident controller Peter Keppel said this morning.

Residents have spent the night in an evacuation centre waiting to find out if their homes are still standing.

When resident Leon Oliver looked at a map strung up in the evacuation centre showing the fire's movements, he discovered the blaze had rampaged right through his house.

"My girlfriend just asked me what we were going to do next and I said, "I don't know, what are we going to do?'" he said.

Joel Hodgson was taken to the refuge centre in Margaret River last night after an emergency evacuation from Prevelly Beach.

Residents were forced to flee when the fire jumped the mouth of the river and hit the small coastal community, damaging a shop and houses.

"All 30 of us huddled underneath the jetty as the fire was raging on the dunes just above us," he said.

Cale Jose, who was among a group of Prevelly residents taken off the beach, says they had to cover themselves with wet towels while they waited to be rescued.

Two fires are burning to the north and north-east of the township of Denmark this morning.

The first at Mt Lindesay National Park was a Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC) prescribed burn which jumped its boundary yesterday.

It has destroyed 4,000 hectares of forest.

Fire crews have not confirmed residents' reports that the second fire close to the town was the result of a permit issued to a landowner.

Local farmer Tony Pedro is angry at what he says are government-sanctioned burns which get out of control and threaten private property.

He says it is time authorities in Western Australia changed their fire-management policy from one of ignition to suppression.

"In summer, the community doesn't light fires ... the farmers don't light fires and if someone does light a fire they're called an arsonist," he said.

"We're surrounded by signs saying 'aerial burning imminent'. It's a bit like living in a war zone. You wait for a hot day and then you wonder 'what on earth's going to happen today? Are we going to get bombed today?'"

DEC controller Brad Barton says controlled burns are still needed.

"We've still got a fairly extensive prescribed burning program, certainly across the wine region," he said.

WA Greens member Giz Watson says a Department of Environment and Conservation decision to conduct controlled burns on a windy, hot day is beyond belief.

Ms Watson says the Department knew the weather forecasts.

"It seems to me a recipe for disaster," she said.

"To spread themselves so thin, that they would actually consider lighting any fires in that sort of conditions. It wasn't a surprise. It was well forecast."

"You have a situation where DEC not only had a fire at Margaret River, but they lit up fires in Denmark, Manjimup and Walpole. It seems to me, a recipe for disaster."

Premier Colin Barnett has promised an inquiry will be held into the Margaret River prescribed burn.

urn:contentItem:4J4S-98T0-TX5J-F251-00000-00'Our forests have too much of the wrong kind of fire'2006-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisOPED2Pg. 79'Our forests have too much of the wrong kind of fire'ATHOL HODGSON

FORMER FIRE CHIEF ATHOL HODGSON SAYS WE HAVE MUCH TO LEARN

AS we saw the unfolding drama of a large number of fires burning hundreds of thousands of hectares across Victoria this week, one thing stood out. A very small number of those fires caused most of the deaths and destruction.

Those few fires started on January 20 in national/state parks, and remained small during benign weather, but became uncontrollable in severe fire weather two days later.

The initial response committed the first cardinal sin of firefighting, namely, failing to make an immediate attack with sufficient force. The same failure occurred in the alpine fires of 2003.

On January 22 the current situation turned feral, feeding on fuels that had accumulated over decades where natural fires had, of necessity, been deliberately extinguished.

Little or nothing had been done to reduce those accumulating fuels by planned burning or any other means.

The current fires burnt large areas with an intensity and uniformity alien to the natural processes that our native forests require for their bio-diversity and sustainability. They burst out of the parks on to private property with distressing effects.

Our native forests must burn because they require fire to survive. We who love and benefit from them must learn to live with forest fires. But neither the forests nor we need feral fires.

The collapse of prescribed burning programs that modified forest fuels over decades before the mid-1980s is well documented and has been criticised by the Auditor-General.

The amount of prescribed burning doubled last year, but coming from a low base, the program is still far short of what can and must be done.

The result is that there is too little of the right, and too much of the wrong, kind of fire in our forests.

Bruce Esplin, Emergency Services Commissioner, reported on the botched prescribed fire lit in Wilsons Promontory on March 21 last year.

Three months ago he reported systemic and cultural shortcomings in firefighting practice.

He said the separation of sections of the Department of Sustainability and Environment into bodies such as Parks Victoria caused a serious disruption in the management of resources for firefighting.

The question must be asked: have we learned anything from the past? Apparently not much. The failure to control the few fires that started on January 20 is symptomatic of political and policy shortcomings at the highest level.

We salute the volunteer firefighters and others who put themselves at risk to save lives and property during events not of their making.

We also salute those who work in our parks and forests, doing their best with a difficult job. They are seriously hampered by the problems identified by Mr Esplin, by absurd regulations, protocols and lack of political support.

ATHOL HODGSON is an internationally recognised expert on forest fires with more than 50 years' experience in fire management and forest fire research in Australia, the US, Canada, France and Spain. He was formerly a chief fire officer, commissioner for forests, member of the board of the Country Fire Authority and the State Disaster Committee.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fires rage in Argentina </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BUENOS AIRES: The Argentine President, Mr Menem, declared a state of emergency in the southern city of Bariloche and the surrounding area yesterday as a raging forest fire advanced through the Andean hills.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighters were unable to contain the blaze that has consumed a hotel, houses and thousands of hectares of forest since starting more than a week ago.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Some 60 Chilean firefighters arrived in the afternoon yesterday in the southern Argentine region, bringing at least one water aircraft and other equipment aimed at extinguishing the raging fires.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP </p></bodyText></section><p>An Interior Ministry spokesman said he had also made similar requests to Brazilian authorities, but there had been no answer late yesterday.</p><p> One potentially bright spot was an outbreak of rain, coming after two months of drought, which officials say has helped the fire-fighting efforts.</p><p> The magnitude of the disaster, which has destroyed vast swathes of virgin forest and was threatening populated areas around Bariloche, led Mr Menem to take the matter out of the hands of Environment Secretary, Ms Maria Julia Alsogaray.</p><p>Ms Alsogaray, the focus of criticism from environmental groups and political and public leaders for her management in the crisis, had assured the President last week that the blaze was contained.</p><p> "She told us the situation was under control and now it's worse," an administration official was quoted as saying in the newspaper Clarin.</p><p> Under Mr Menem's declaration of the interior security law, the Interior Minister, Mr Carlos Corach, is responsible for ordering the mobilisation of military troops and increasing security in order to stop the flames from encroaching on Bariloche, about 1,800km south of Buenos Aires.</p><p> The chief concern is the fire's advance on the Cerro Catedral ski resort, where flames destroyed eight buildings at the weekend. Tourists who had been camping or staying in cabins and hostels on the mountain were evacuated safely to hotels in Bariloche, officials said.</p><p> Other fires have devastated the forests in the Nahuel Huapi National Park near here, where an estimated one million trees were destroyed.</p><p> Thousands of hectares of old growth forest also have been incinerated by fire in Lago Puebla in the province of Chubut.</p><p> The Government has made no estimate of the extent of the loss.</p><p>But environmentalists were calling it one of the worst ecological disasters in Argentina in years.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: Fires claim 100,000 hectares in erratic behaviour</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Catherine McAloon and Lisa Walker</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 20</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fires in Victoria's north-east have claimed more than 100,000 hectares of bushland ahead of another predicted tough day for firefighters tomorrow.</p><p nitf:lede="true">High temperatures and strong winds caused erratic fire conditions in the area today and extreme weather conditions are predicted for the north-east tomorrow.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The CFA has declared a total fire ban in the state's north-east region tomorrow and firefighters have warned a potentially dangerous wind change was due.</p><p>Department of Sustainability and Environment chief fire officer Gary Morgan said the wind change around noon would bring the "highest fire behaviour".</p><p>"Tomorrow brings us a heightened degree of fire risk across the state," Mr Morgan said.</p><p>Six fires burning in the state's east, have blazed through more than 100,000 hectares since they were started by lightning 14 days ago.</p><p>"This is the most serious fire situation that we have dealt with in the last several decades," Mr Morgan said.</p><p>More than 20 properties were placed under threat today, and residents were urged to evacuate or implement bushfire action plans at two properties in Nariel Valley, near Benambra.</p><p>The three main fires are at Pinnabar in the Upper Murray south of Corryong, Mt Buffalo and the Bogong region.</p><p>The Mt Buffalo fire is expected to breach containment lines as weather conditions deteriorate.</p><p>Fires in the Bogong region are threatening property and assets at Harrietville, Smoko, Mt Beauty, Benambra, Omeo, Hotham and Dinner Plain, and backburning patrols are continuing in these areas.</p><p>The Pinnabar fire has destroyed a communications tower and burned through more than 20,000 hectares of bushland.</p><p>Heavy smoke caused problems getting fire aircraft in the air during the day, but conditions are expected to change later this evening.</p><p>Thirteen New Zealand firefighters with specialist forest fire knowledge helped relieve fire crews today, and about 90 Army Reserve engineers will tomorrow start building firebreaks in preparation for backburning.</p><p>So far this fire season, 622 fires have burned 316,120 hectares in Victoria, compared to the 20-year average of 312 fires annually burning 41,443 hectares.</p><p>Smoke from the bushfires, combined with those in Canberra and NSW, caused a thick haze over Melbourne and other parts of Victoria, with the EPA reporting poor air quality across the state.</p><p>Matches at the Australian Open were not affected by smoke, but were paused due to high temperatures at 2.30pm (AEDT) today.</p><p>The smoky haze forced Qantas to divert two Melbourne-bound international flights to Sydney.</p><p>Smoke also caused several call-outs for respiratory problems across the city.</p><p>A spokesperson for Metropolitan Ambulance Service said 45 people were treated for shortness of breath before 4pm.</p><p>A further fire broke out this afternoon near the historic northern Victorian town of Glenrowan.</p><p>Four aircraft were deployed to the grassfire which was burning on a 100 metre front.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49N0-D1M0-01S8-G2C6-00000-00<published>1991-10-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FEDERAL FORCES CLOSE ON CROATIAN CAPITAL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>AAPINTNEWS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Federal forces close on Croatian capital BELGRADE: Serbian-led federal troops pushed Croatia's militia to within 32km of the secessionist republic's capital yesterday, news reports said. Despite the fighting, Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic and federal Defence Minister General Veljko Kadijevic met with Croatian President Franjo Tudjman at European Community-mediated talks in the Hague. The EC has negotiated at least six short-lived truces to try to halt the fighting between rival Serbs and Croats, in which more than 600 people have been killed since non-communist Croatia declared independence in June. The federal army has sided with ethnic Serbs, who refuse to be a part of an independent Croatia, and together they have seized about one-third of the breakaway republic. The battlefield action follows communist Serbia's consolidation of political control yesterday over what remains of Yugoslavia. Stipe Mesic, the Croat chairman of the federal presidency, said yesterday's takeover of the nearly defunct Parliament was a Serbian-organised coup. But Mr Kadijevic said the army only wanted ""to establish control in crisis areas, protect the Serbian population from genocide and free army personnel and members of their families under blockade in Croatia". The army, which launched a major assault against Croatia this week, bombarded areas around historic Dubrovnik, starting a forest fire. The Borba newspaper in Belgrade said 26 federal soldiers had died in three days of fighting. Zagreb radio reported that hundreds of women and children fled the village of Slano, near Dubrovnik, after a fierce mortar attack.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Western military attaches in Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital, said they doubted Croat resistance could hold up longer than 10 days. Yugoslav navy warships closed off Dubrovnik, which has been without water or power for three days. Gen Andrija Raseta, deputy commander of the federal military district, gave assurances the army would not destroy the fortified city, one of Europe's historic treasures. Associated PressCROATIAN refugees leave the village of Pokupsko after heavy shelling by the federal army.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF CROATIAN REFUGEES LEAVING THE VILLAGE OF POKUPSKO AFTER ATTACK BY THE FEDERAL ARMY</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P6W-1DJ0-TXN5-R30M-00000-00Fireys spend $2m on travel, advice2002-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 5Fireys spend $2m on travel, advicePaola Totaro, State Political Editor

The Rural Fire Service spent nearly $2 million on travel and consultants last year, enough to lease another Erickson Air-Crane helitanker for 166 hours of work, it has been claimed.

The spending was detailed in the fire service's annual report, which also shows hazard reduction work dropped from 589,319 hectares in 2000-01 to 581,825 hectares. The most significant drop was in western NSW, from 213,649 hectares in 2000 to 151,709 last year.

The report says the NSW Treasury also cut its proportion of funding for the service by1 per cent last year, while local government was forced to increase its funding by the equivalent percentage.

The report, which triggered criticism from the State Opposition, shows funding is now split among:

* The insurance industry, through its levy, which pays 73.7 per cent of annual contributions, bringing the total to $83.3 million last year, up from $67 million in 2001;

* Local government, which paid out $15 million last year (13.3 per cent), up from 12.3 per cent, or $11.2 million, in 2001;

* NSW Treasury funds, which represented 13 per cent, or $16.4 million, last year compared to 14 per cent, or $12.7 million. (The 2002 allocation included a $700,000 supplement from Treasury.)

The report also shows that officials from the service took 10 overseas trips, including visits to China, Thailand, Singapore and Bhutan. The visits were to discuss business, forest fire management, a community fire management project and service improvements.

The Opposition's Treasury spokesman, George Souris, said the service should be ordered to return its focus to fighting fires, not drumming up business.

"Ten overseas trips what do these trips have to do with protecting the people of NSW from the scourge of bushfires?" he asked. "Government agencies which focus themselves on overseas business development become a travel agency for their own bureaucrats."

A fire service spokesman replied that hazard reduction in the state's west had been reduced because the drought had slashed fuel loads, reducing the need for such work. Consultancy fees had only increased from $653,437 to $840,592 last year.

Consultants were required to help the service "reach its goals at a reasonable cost", he said.

"[The $937,000 in travel costs] primarily relate to ... flights, car hire, taxis and reimbursements," the spokesman said. "These travel costs are vital in servicing our rural communities and the brigades that support them.

"[The 10 overseas] trips were revenue generating and have allowed an overall increase in funding for the broader service of $1.15 million."

He said the reduced funding percentage from Treasury was because of a change in the funding formula, after district fire control staff were transferred to the payroll of the State Government.

"The total funding provided by Treasury has actually risen in dollar terms and total RFS funding has increased from $90.9 million to $113 million in that period."

urn:contentItem:7W6S-0DV1-2PW5-F1W2-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 July 222009-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 July 22

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
EUR: Flu toll climbs to 700 as schools closure mulled
   GENEVA, July 21 AFP - Swine flu has now killed more than 700 people around the globe, the World Health Organisation says, as experts debate whether schools should be closed to contain the pandemic. (FLU WORLD sent at 03:24, 628 words.)


MID: Iraq bomb attacks kill 21
   BAGHDAD, July 21 AFP - Twenty-one people were killed in a spate of bomb attacks across Iraq on Tuesday, one of the deadliest days of violence in the country since US troops left its cities three weeks ago. (IRAQ BLASTS Update sent at 04:34, 523 words.)
ASIA: Five killed as suicide bombers attack Afghan cities
   KHOST, Afghanistan, July 21 AFP - Taliban suicide bombers, most of them disguised as women, have tried to storm government buildings and a military base in two Afghan cities, killing five people, officials said. (AFGHAN BOMBS sent at 02:11, 670 words.)
ASIA: Thousands throng to village in India for eclipse
   TAREGNA, India, July 21 AP - Hordes of scientists, students and nature enthusiasts prepared on Tuesday for the longest total solar eclipse of this century, while millions planned to shutter themselves indoors, giving in to superstitious myths about the phenomenon. (INDIA ECLIPSE sent at 01:20, 609 words.)
US: Obama popularity lower than Bush's at six-month mark: poll
   WASHINGTON, July 21 AFP - President Barack Obama's tumbling poll numbers have dipped below those of his predecessor George W. Bush at the same point in his White House tenure, according to a national poll released on Tuesday. (US OBAMA sent at 00:33, 276 words.)
CAM: Honduras orders Venezuelan diplomats expelled
   TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 21 AP - Honduras' interim government has ordered Venezuelan diplomats to leave the country as the international community threatened new sanctions on the Central American nation if negotiations fail to resolve the crisis. (HONDURAS sent at 06:04, 491 words.)
CAN: Some Canada forest fire evacuees return home
   VANCOUVER, July 21 AFP - Police have allowed 6,000 people to return to their homes in western Canada, as firefighters gained partial control of a wildfire threatening the town of West Kelowna. (CANADA FIRE sent at 06:46, 333 words.)
EUR: More heat on Israel over East Jerusalem settlements
      BRUSSELS, July 21 AFP - Israel has come under intense diplomatic heat  over its settlement activity in occupied East Jerusalem, with the European Union and Russia warning it not to violate a Middle East peace plan. (MIDEAST ISRAEL Update sent at 04:06, 563 words.)
JPN: Six dead, nine missing in Japan downpours: officials
   TOKYO, July 21 AFP - Torrential rains triggered scores of floods and landslides in western Japan on Tuesday, leaving at least six people dead and nine more missing, police and other officials said. (JAPAN LANDSLIDE sent at 03:15, 274 words.)
IRE: New 'shock' report into Irish church sex abuse
   DUBLIN, July 21 AFP - A shocking new report has identified hundreds of victims of child sex abuse by Irish Catholic priests, officials and clerics say, two months after a landmark study found "endemic" mistreatment. (IRELAND ABUSE sent at 23:44, 304 words.)
ASIA: Dutch couple identified as Jakarta bomb victims: police
   JAKARTA, July 21 AFP - A Dutch couple have been identified as victims of last week's suicide bombing at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Jakarta, Indonesian police said today. (INDON BLASTS DUTCH sent at 20:58, 66 words.)
ASIA: SKorean auto workers resist calls to stop strike
   SEOUL, South Korea, July 21 AP - Helicopters sprayed tear gas on militant auto workers using slingshots to shoot nuts and bolts at riot police Tuesday amid a tense labor dispute at the main factory of an ailing South Korean automaker. (KOREA SSANGYONG sent at 20:55, 698 words.)
EUR: Sea lion dies in German zoo during mating season
   BERLIN, July 21 AFP - A male sea lion from California called Mike has died of exhaustion after over-exerting himself during the mating season in an animal park in Nuremberg, Germany, the city said on Tuesday. (GERMANY SEA LION sent at 02:43, 203 words.)

urn:contentItem:4R8P-P1P0-TX4S-M0MB-00000-00FoI laws can hinder government decision-making process2007-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisAPg. 12FoI laws can hinder government decision-making processThe Canberra Times

Peter Harding (Letters, December 2) doesn't understand how Freedom of Information legislation can inhibit public servants from giving their ministers frank and fearless advice.

A broad answer is that government can't function properly, and make sound policy decisions, unless there are "back room" people with whom government can discuss frankly, and in confidence, options and their consequences in formulating its policies, before putting them to the public.

Freedom of Information runs the risk of abolishing or weakening that essential process, by admitting the media and the public into the "back room".

It's equivalent to insisting on a company's shareholders taking part in the detailed working-up of company policies by the board and its executives and employees.

A more specific answer is that many government policies, although perhaps benefiting the nation as a whole, can cause hardship to the public, or sections of the public.

And ministers need to be told openly and frankly the likely consequences when formulating their policies, no matter how "draconian" they might be.

But public service advisers, being human, are likely to allow their advice on such matters is be influenced by the knowledge that what they have said could become known, before policies have been adopted, to those likely to be adversely affected most likely through the media, the main users of the Freedom of Information process.

R.S. Gilbert, Turner Forest management Where is the balance in environmental journalism today?

Rosslyn Beeby ignored the truth about forest types and Australia's sustainable forest management in her front-page article that reported on the Federal Court's decision upholding the legality of forest management in Wielangta forest ("Garrett facing his first forest fire", December 1, p1).

Instead Beeby garnished Greens leader Bob Brown's call for the federal Environment Minister to intervene.

Canberra Times readers were told that Wielangta forest is an old-growth rainforest. This is not true.

Then we were led to believe that forest management in Australia could embarrass our Government at the climate change conference in Bali.

Again there is no basis for this statement aside from Brown's layperson views on forests.

The Australian Government can proudly showcase sustainable forest management at Bali.

If more governments in the Asia- Pacific region were able to enforce sustainable forest management, as our Government does, the Bali conference could reach a long way towards its objective to reduce greenhouse emissions from forest clearing.

Peter Langdon, Institute of Foresters of Australia, ACT Division Timor population Virginia Haussegger ("New government should make East Timor a priority", December 1, pB7) expresses concern over East Timor: it could be tragedy without end unless there is fundamental change.

"East Timor has one of the world's fastest growing populations, highest fertility rates, highest infant and maternal mortality rates." Fast growing populations are very demanding upon social services.

Australia, with population growth close to world average, seems unable to meet such demands to the standard expected for a developed nation.

The heavy burden of both developing talent and maintaining health from maternity through into the workforce is onerous. And it seems beyond us.

Australia is forced to import professionals trained by others.

How much worse for East Timor, which has 36percent of its population 0-14 years of age, double Australia's proportion. This developing nation faces an impossible task. What hope is there while children reach adolescence poorly educated, with little prospect of enriching employment ahead of them?

They are prey to mentoring by elder peers steeped in hate against other competitive groups. Hope will remain thin while parents are unable to reduce their excessive fertility.

Colin Samundsett, Farrer
