urn:contentItem:4HFJ-FC70-015G-T4VP-00000-00<published>2005-10-31T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>ED; Pg. 22</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Herald Sun EDITORIAL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">April fools put to torch</p><p nitf:lede="true">THE scathing report over the Department of Sustainability and Environment's incompetence over the Wilson's Promontory fire must make rural communities feel apprehensive.</p><p nitf:lede="true">It indicates basic problems in how DSE handles fire fighting have not been fully addressed after the 2002-2003 bushfires.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The State Government claims fuel-reduction burning has been doubled.</p><p>But farmers and two expert reports claim the Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin's inquiry into 2002-2003 did not get to the crux of poor DSE practice prior to and during that summer.</p><p>Now Mr Esplin's report on Wilson's Promontory 2005 will add to concerns.</p><p>The State Government released it the Friday before Derby Day.</p><p>That reeks of a pattern of obstruction and avoidance by both DSE and Parks Victoria when the Herald Sun raised questions over their performance.</p><p>Why did the State Government insist on spruiking about 200 new firefighters hired when a Forest Fire Victoria independent report showed up to 220 seasonal fighters were let go in the weeks before the Wilson's Promontory fiasco?</p><p>The new Esplin report confirms the lamentable preparations for the burn-off, failure to follow procedure, understaffing, and incompetent warnings of the wildfire that placed 600 campers' lives at risk.</p><p>There was a broken fire-warning signal, then failed attempts to re-hire firefighters just sacked to fight the burn-off, out of control on April Fools' night.</p><p>Now we face another fire season. An ageing DSE workforce and what Mr Esplin called its "risk culture" must be reformed.</p><p>Better than tax</p><p>THIS year's $13.6 billion Budget surplus plus future surpluses could deliver an $18-a-week tax cut for all Australians, research for the Herald Sun has found.</p><p>Yet Treasurer Peter Costello refuses to comment on the Econtech figures which show he could cut average tax from 23.3 per cent to 21.8 per cent, across all brackets.</p><p>In Canberra and at Spring St, politicians keep a surplus for a rainy poll day when they shower voters with promises, as the Howard Government did in 2004.</p><p>Yet ex-premier Jeff Kennett may be right in seeing better community priorities.</p><p>While the Government is fixated with labour market reform, the physical infrastructure that allows Australia to compete is in urgent need of extra capacity.</p><p>The problems of health services, water savings, our future power needs, port capacity, the need for a safer national highway, transport congestion and inadequate services to booming suburban areas must be addressed.</p><p>Need we go on? These politically tough, big ticket items would help Australia in coming decades when a tax cut is a forgotten piece of history.</p><p>History under hoof</p><p>MAKYBE Diva's entry into the Melbourne Cup may answer the prayer of every mug punter and expert who wants to know -- do we have a new Phar Lap?</p><p>Trainer Lee Freedman is worried about the injury risk to his star from a firm track, as is Vinnie Roe's trainer Dermot Weld.</p><p>Pressure is on track staff to have Flemington in top shape so we see history's verdict.</p><p>DEATHS ON OUR ROADS</p><p>THIS YEAR 299</p><p>LAST YEAR 288</p><p>Victorian deaths in 2005, compared with the same day last year.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P8B-H2K0-TXN5-R01H-00000-00Rewinding with new friends2000-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisMETROPOLITANPg. 17Rewinding with new friendsReviewed by Bernard Zuel

LLOYD COLE

The Basement, November 29

Lloyd Cole's mid-'80s incarnation had all the world-weariness of the well-read middle-class boy who was merely anticipating experiences and all the studied ennui he had only read about or listened to. As he wryly noted on Wednesday, he wrote about mid-life crises when he was 26.

Now 39 with a cultivated stubble and salt-and-pepper hair, he's relaxed into that life, less concerned with showiness (be it wit or erudition or pop hooks) than communication. He has not wearied at all, still finding grace in unlikely corners and displaying a low-key bonhomie that delivered humour without gags and justified an old line about "listening to Arthur Lee records, making all your friends so guilty about their cynicism".

Though he told us that "when I was 23, though I loved them, I thought Mott the Hoople were rather pathetic because all their songs were about being in a rock and roll band. Now I want to be them", this Lloyd Cole is closer to a folk singer. Close quarters singing in a voice that can croak when necessary (Brand New Friend) but also gently slide by (No More Love Songs), he overcame his limitations on guitar something noticeable in the more jangly Commotions songs to present a convincing argument for simplicity.

This became clearer in the darker second set, which was less pop-oriented (at least until half an hour in when Perfect Skin induced a spontaneous singalong) with a song such as Like Lovers Do sounding reborn shorn of its recorded finery. A black country take on Nick Cave's People Ain't No Good (following Cole's own dramatic Cut Me Down) in this context didn't jar at all. And honestly, nothing jarred: Cole's quality back catalogue reminds you how much good music of the past decade has never seen the light of radio day.

A word of warning: Cole's first set doesn't begin until 10.30 and he finishes after 1am. Being at the Basement, a venue contemptuous of genuine music fans who don't want to stump up for the hardly cheap food and must settle for being crammed up the back with no sightlines, it makes for a hot, long and crowded night. You are rewarded for staying late (particularly if you want to hear Forest Fire), but it's also worth getting there early to see Chuck Jenkins of Icecream Hands perform some delicious '60s-influenced pop.

Lloyd Cole's show tonight is sold out.

urn:contentItem:7W2B-8DX1-2RG6-Y2XV-00000-00Damning recommendations from Black Saturday commission2009-07-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisLateline10:59 PM AESTABCJane CowanDamning recommendations from Black Saturday commission

TONY JONES, PRESENTER: Lawyers assisting the Royal Commission into the Black Saturday bushfires will tomorrow recommend a sweeping overhaul of Victoria's fire safety systems, and they have devastating criticism for Victoria's bushfire chief.

The ABC has obtained a copy of their recommendations for the Commission's interim report due in August.

Counsel assisting argue that the controversial "stay or go" policy should be drastically revised to include selective evacuations for those in imminent danger and they also urge the reinstatement of community fire refuges.

Counsel assisting also take aim at the head of the State's Country Fire Authority, saying his role on the day was divorced from his proper responsibilities.

Jane Cowan has this report.

JANE COWAN, REPORTER: Victoria's bushfires devastated whole communities. Now counsel assisting the Commission want radical change. Draft documents obtained by the ABC suggest the Commissions will be asked to drastically rework the contentious "stay or go" policy. It's been under question since it's been revealed 113 off those who died on Black Saturday were trying to shelter inside houses. Now alongside the option to stay and defend, communities under threat will be told when evacuation is recommended. But they won't be forced to go.

According to the draft recommendations community fire refuges should be revived. They could be in parks, shopping centres or even dams.

PETER MARSHALL, UNITED FIREFIGHTERS UNION: This is a chance for a bipartisan approach by Victoria's fire services and the political parties of this State to fix the problem once and for all.

JANE COWAN: Also favoured by the Commission's legal team - use of the alert tone played in northern Australia to warn of cyclones and sirens for towns that want them, something that's been resisted by authorities in the past.

PETER MARSHALL: The recommendations are on the right track but the Government should be compelled to implement the recommendations not just allow them to sit on the shelf like previous inquests. That's our greatest fear. They should be compelled. We owe that to the people who have perished in these fires.

JANE COWAN: The counsel assisting the Commission also makes a damning assessment of Victoria's fire agencies. They say authorities were not prepared for Black Saturday, even as they warned the community to get ready. The CFA boss, Russell Rees is singled out for criticism. Senior Counsel assisting Jack Rush QC describes his role on the day as divorced from fundamental aspects of the responsibilities of chief officer. They included the provision of public warnings and the protection of life.

TONY CUTCLIFFE, BUSHFIRE CONSULTANT: In my opinion, anyone involved in emergency services who is not absolutely up to that task is a dangerous person and there's no place for them in public administration.

JANE COWAN: In particular counsel assisting say Mr Rees should have made himself aware of fire maps that predicted the path of the fires hours before they destroyed homes and claimed lives.

TONY CUTCLIFFE: It is absolutely essential that the counsel assisting identifies those leaders and emergency services who don't have his confidence and he must make a recommendation that they go and that they go now.This is like dealing with a surgeon. If a surgeon is implicated in a large number of deaths they remove their licence to operate.

JANE COWAN: Tonight the CFA told the ABC it has full confidence in the fire chief and expects him to be at helm again this summer.

Whatever changes are made, as it stands now the same management team that presided over the system which failed to cope on Black Saturday will be required to implement the new regime. Some say that's a problem.

TONY CUTCLIFFE: We still have people running these organisations who are predominately devoted to a fire-fighting technology that is no longer in vogue, let alone being attuned to the needs of behavioural management and leadership.

JANE COWAN: In other proposed recommendations, the weather bureau will be encouraged to tell the public about the forecast forest fire danger index, something normally only circulated within the ranks of emergency services.

And the ABC might lose its monopoly as the emergency broadcaster. Commercial operators could be invited into similar arrangements.

Jane Cowan, Lateline.

urn:contentItem:458W-JRK0-0197-84PN-00000-00<published>1998-06-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE, SPORT; Pg. 62</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>The stain that won't go away</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BRUCE WILSON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DEVOTEES of the Peanuts comic strip will know that, year in and year out, Lucy offers to hold the football for Charlie Brown, promising that this time she will not whisk it away at the last moment.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Every time, though, she does, and every time Charlie Brown falls flat on his back. If you live, as I do, in England, that is how you feel about England, soccer and football violence.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Year in and year out Scotland Yard, the FA and the clubs tell us that, this time, there will not be violence by England fans, that all hooligans have been identified, that the most sophisticated intelligence operation since M ran 007 was underway to stop it.</p><p> Every time, though, there we all are, flat on our backs again as the yobs run riot, as they did yesterday in Marseille until the French riot police got them under control.</p><p>Britain's Sports Minister, a football nut called Tony Banks, called the rioters in Marseilles "a moronic minority of drunken, brain-dead louts" but that excuse just won't wash anymore.</p><p> Eye-witnesses, including British journalists, are adamant the thugs were as well-organised as a military unit.</p><p> Their leaders were heard shouting orders, telling their troops to stand firm in the face of French baton charges, a thin red line of thuggery. Or, rather, red, white and blue because all these jokers will tell you that they are patriots, fighting for England and justice.</p><p> In this case, the excuse is the rotten French failed to make enough tickets available. There are reported to be 20,000 British fans in Marseille, of whom only 9000 have tickets. But that is not the issue; the issue is how did the 20,000 get there, find somewhere to stay and carry with them the dregs of British soccer hooliganism?</p><p> Already there is the pathetic chant of "we were provoked". But it was clear this was not random violence; once it started, it erupted like a planned battle not a sudden forest fire.</p><p> The real fighters in these guerrilla wars aren't drunks but genuine men of violence, hard-eyed and sober. And by no means in the first flush of youth. Many are veterans of 20-year campaigns.</p><p> In Marseille yesterday, some of the fighters were identified by British police as known football thugs allegedly under court-ordered travel restrictions. Yet they made it to southern France, all right. Some travel restrictions; some intelligence; some policing.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:53NB-C9H1-JD3N-539M-00000-00"Complacency by property owners and restricted government resources are the ingredients of a tragic fire season2011-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 18"Complacency by property owners and restricted government resources are the ingredients of a tragic fire seasonREX JORY

SOUTH Australia appears to be alarmingly under-prepared for the coming bushfire season. The Adelaide Hills are a potential disaster area. Their lush forest growth, particularly in built-up areas, is a trigger for a potential community tragedy of unimaginable proportions.

In no way am I attempting to criticise or underestimate the work done by SA's professional or volunteer fire fighters. Their efforts and their willingness to risk their lives to keep rural areas safe is beyond question.

And I hope I am wrong about the bushfire potential. I hope I can be rebuked, even embarrassed, for issuing such irresponsible warnings.

I hope I can be assured that responsible authorities are monitoring the situation, eliminating hot spots and are confident that somehow a catastrophe will be avoided for another summer. And I hope that in six months SA will have negotiated the summer free of serious bushfires.

But I fear complacency and neglect by property owners together with restricted government resources have slowly allowed the ingredients for a tragic fire season to be stirred together.

It's nearly 30 years since the terrible SA bushfires of the early 1980s and even the 2005 and 2009 fires at Port Lincoln are a fading memory. It is easy to become complacent and overconfident. There seems to be a belief that bushfires, like road accidents, happen to other people.

Drive into the Adelaide Hills and it is clear that the fuel load in built-up and heavily populated areas is the touch-paper for disaster.

It would be all but impossible to save many properties from an advancing bushfire. The potential loss of life is too frightening to contemplate.

The Adelaide Hills, and other rural areas in SA, are uniquely beautiful. Understandably people want to live in this wonderful environment and share their homes and gardens with nature.

Many home owners have merged with the neighbouring forests or turned pocket-handkerchief suburbs into nature parks by planting trees and undergrowth perilously close to houses.

When planting a 60cm tree in a virgin garden it is hard to imagine that in perhaps 20 years it will tower above house height and wave leafy branches, heavy with combustible eucalyptus oil, over the roofs. Beautiful, of course. But madness in bushfire-prone areas.

It is easy to ignore the bushfire potential in the opening week of spring because of the lush green bush. The hillsides weep from the abundant consumption of winter rain and creeks and gullies chatter with flowing water. When first we practise to deceive.

Twice in a week I was reminded of the looming fire threat. Former Victorian Police Commissioner, Christine Nixon - whose career was stained by her role in the 2009 Victorian bushfires - was the guest speaker at a recent Press Club lunch. She warned us of the imminent dangers faced in many areas of Australia by bushfires.

Then I received a handwritten letter from an old mate, social activist and conservationist, Betty Fisher, who said she recently visited the Adelaide Hills.

``It's just shocking,'' she writes. ``No one is taking any notice - trees everywhere, hanging over houses, driveway arches of all sorts of trees, no roadside clearings.

``Wherever we looked I couldn't see anywhere that didn't contravene the fire-risk regulations, if they exist.

``We could be in for another inferno as things are. Whom to write, as you do, I've no idea. To whom to write to ask the questions? The CFS? The Local Government Ministers? The new Premier? The old Premier, the Minister for Water Supplies to Hills Councils? The list is endless.''

And, ``Right or wrong, the Hills seemed to us to have a huge under-story of season after season of non-clearance. I was alarmed at what I saw.''

So was I, Betty. You've written about the dangers far more eloquently than I can and you've asked the hard questions.

What we need now is for someone to come up with satisfactory answers.

COUNTING THE COST

Between 1939 and 2007, 58 people died in South Australia as a result of bushfires.

In 1983, 28 people died in fires which ravaged much of the state, particularly the Adelaide Hills, the Clare region and the South-East. In the same period, 47 people died in fires in Victoria.

Of those who died in the 1983 Ash Wednesday fires, 12 were in the Hills and 14 in the South-East. A further 2676 people were injured.

The total cost of the 1983 fires in SA was more than $200 million (1983 values) and 4540 insurance claims were paid. More than 250,000 sheep and cattle were killed.

In 2005, nine people died in fires on the Eyre Peninsula while, in 1958, eight people died in the Wandilo pine forest fire.

Between 1960 and 1983 and between 1984 and 2005 there were no bushfire fatalities in SA.

urn:contentItem:7VH6-GRN1-2RYX-10VF-00000-00NO CHANCE Fatal fire flaws to be exposed2009-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1NO CHANCE Fatal fire flaws to be exposedNorrie Ross

BUSHFIRE victims had no idea they were in danger from ``atomic force'' fireballs on Black Saturday because Victoria's warning system broke down.

The opening day of the bushfire royal commission was told people stayed in their homes unaware of the inferno approaching.

Counsel assisting the commission, Jack Rush, QC, said the warning system failed to cope with the speed of the fires and the public had no accurate or timely information.

He said the ``stay or go early'' warning system might have misled people who did not understand what they were facing.

The 000 emergency line and other warning systems would also be examined.

``Why would a resident of any of the fire-affected regions implement the `go' part of the policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?'' Mr Rush said yesterday.

``(People) who chose to stay and defend their properties did so entirely unaware of the severity, the extremity, the intensity of the fires they would face.''

The bushfire disaster killed 173 people.

Continued Page 4

From Page 1

The opening day of the commission was dogged by complaints that individual survivors were being denied the right to give evidence.

There were complaints the commission had been hijacked by the interests of government departments, councils, emergency services, insurance and power companies.

Mat Tinkler, of the Public Interest Law Clearing House, said applications from the

30 individuals and communities he represented were rejected without their barristers even getting the chance to put their case.

``Money is no object for the big players, who are briefing the country's top lawyers to appear,'' he said. ``Survivors and communities that were devastated by the fires have been provided with no funded assistance to seek leave to appear or make submissions.''

Premier John Brumby refused to buy into the argument over representation.

``I'm not going to comment on the specific decisions made by the commission,'' he said.

``I made it very clear that I wanted this to be a commission for the people.

``I wanted to have the broadest possible terms of reference and that's what we put through the Parliament.''

Commission chairman Bernard Teague said leave to appear was granted to a limited number of applicants. He urged others to have their say in written submissions.

In his opening address, Mr Rush said the forest fire danger index had predicted February 7 would be the worst fire danger day ever in Victoria.

A figure of 50 was considered ``extreme'', but on Black Saturday it ranged between 120 and 180. In such catastrophic conditions normal warnings became useless.

``The risk that the index indicated carried with it the potential of a fire that could not be fought,'' he said.

Mr Rush said the first issues considered would be the warnings and the ``stay or go early'' policy.

He said one view of ``leave early'' meant evacuating before 10am on a day of total fire ban.

At midday on Black Saturday, there was no reported fire in Kilmore East, Horsham, Kinglake, Marysville, Strathewen, Callignee, Bendigo or Coleraine.

An expert will give evidence to the commission that people have no knowledge of the triggers of when to leave early and when it is too late to leave.

Mr Rush said that on Black Saturday Victoria recorded its highest temperatures since records began in 1859, soaring into the high 40s and with wind over 100km/h.

He said the maximum intensity at which a bushfire can be controlled is expressed as 4000 kilowatts a metre.

On Black Saturday the intensity reached 100,000 kilowatts a metre.

``Not only the intensity of the fire, the heat of the fire, but its speed was phenomenal,'' Mr Rush said.

The commission will present an interim report by August 17 and a final report by July 31 next year.

POLICE want to speak to two women who may have witnessed how a deadly Black Saturday fire near Bendigo began. The women went to the Eaglehawk CFA station within minutes of each other about 4.20pm to report the Maiden Gully fire that killed Long Gully man Kevin ``Mick'' Kane, 48, and injured 41 others.

Editorial, Page 22

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H0Y0-TXN5-R14V-00000-00Heat is on for chopper pilots2000-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 3Heat is on for chopper pilotsPhilip Cornford

The critical time above a bushfire for a fire bomber lasts 10 to 15 seconds. "It can get rough as guts," said helicopter pilot Mr John McDermott. "And it's hot, mate. It's hot."

The fires create their own wind storms which toss the helicopters around, "white-knuckle flying".

Dense smoke reduces visibility to zero dangerous. The smoke carries cinders which can choke a turbine and put the helicopter into the fire. Even worse.

"You don't hover around," said Mr McDermott, 44, who on Saturday flew his Bell Huey on 50 water-bombing missions over a fire at Hornsby Heights. "There's no point in killing yourself it won't put out the fire."

Mr McDermott, owner of McDermott Aviation, based on the Sunshine Coast, flew one of 36 helicopters and four planes which the Rural Fire Service called into action at the weekend more aircraft than were used during the 10-day crisis in 1994, when hundreds of major fires threatened Sydney.

The contract rates are about $2,000 an hour flying time. No-one disagrees that the pilots earn their money.

With the doors removed and the fire blasting hot air "It's like a furnace" into his face, Mr McDermott hovered 20 metres above the tree tops and dropped his load of 1,400 litres of water.

But with all the dangers above the fire, the worst threat came from elsewhere: the power lines draped across the ridges, hard to see in clear air, impossible under smoke screens.

The pilots operate alone, so the missions require deft, vigilant flying, with the helicopters loaded close to maximum capacity and watched by a circling "bird dog" helicopter from which a Rural Fire Service air attack officer directs the activities

of three helicopters.

The water was scooped from a "buoy wall", a 15,000-litre mobile dam established by the RFS on a sports oval two minutes' flying time from the fire, constantly refilled by tankers.

Mr McDermott flew two hours over the fire, returned to base at Rosehill for refuelling and a drink of water. Within 15 minutes he was in the air again and four minutes later he was back over the fire.

Three McDermott Aviation choppers flew from Queensland to Tenterfield to fight a forest fire on Friday, after which Mr McDermott was routed to Sydney, part of a back-up force of 300 helicopters and planes in NSW, Queensland and Victoria that the RFS can call on in emergencies.

ILLUS: Pilot John McDermott (top) and his engineer brother, Bruce.

Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: RAIN IN BORNEO DOUSES FOREST FIRES, SAYS OFFICIAL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, April 24 Reuters - Most of the raging forest fires devastating Indonesia's Borneo province of East Kalimantan are out, partly because of rain, partly because there is nothing left to burn, an Environment Ministry official said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "A large part of the fires, about 70 per cent, have been extinguished, not just by the rains but because there is nothing left to burn," said Murdiansyah of the East Kalimantan Environment Impact Management Agency (BAPEDAL), an arm of the Environment Ministry.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Murdiansyah told Reuters by telephone from the East Kalimantan town of Samarinda that the area received light rain at the beginning of the week - then had a huge downpour today.</p><p>He said the number of hotspots in East Kalminantan had been reduced from more than 360 to 13.</p><p> The fires on Borneo, which Indonesia shares with Malaysia and Brunei, are not confined to East Kalimantan, but they have been at their worst there.</p><p> At a meeting in Geneva this week the United Nations said the Indonesian fires threatened to become a global disaster and agreed on an urgent action plan to provide equipment and training for 1,000 local firefighters.</p><p> The Borneo fires have produced clouds of choking smog which forced Brunei to shut down schools and cut office working hours.</p><p> Much of Southeast Asia - blanketed by smog for three months late last year from fires on the Indonesian island of Sumatra - fears a repetition this year.</p><p> Last year's fires caused billions of dollars of damage to economies, with tourism well down, and widespread health problems. Smoke from this year's fires on Borneo has drifted as far as Singapore, more than 1,000km away.</p><p> Murdiansyah said the weather outlook was promising for East Kalimantan.</p><p> "We expect more rain in the coming weeks as we can see the presence of cumulus clouds above the East Kalimantan forest fire area," he said.</p><p> The rains are unusual for this time of the year, when the dry season is due to start. It usually runs from April to September.</p><p> According to the Indonesia Meteorology and Geophysics Department, the rainfall is caused by the El Nino phenomenon which has changed weather patterns.</p><p> "The rains which were meant for the rainy season, but which did not arrive, have now come during the dry season," said Waan Tarmin of the Meteorology Department.</p><p> El Nino - "the boy child" in Spanish - results from a warming of surface waters of the Pacific off Peru.</p><p>REUTERS gm/</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJ1-G8M0-0048-T1M7-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="411"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4GWP-6DV0-01W7-649S-00000-00<published>2005-08-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>ADVERTISING FEATURE; Pg. 31</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Amazing Thailand</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Dr Martin Hooper recently spent about five weeks as a Visiting Professor at King Mongkhut's University in Thailand. This is one trip he took.</p><p nitf:lede="true">AMAZING Thailand  this phrase, adopted in promotion some years back, has stuck and is now frequently used when farang meets Thai.</p><p>The street marketplace, with cheap, copied, brand-named goods, is only one face of this amazing country.</p><p>It was July 19 and time to visit the teak forests in Northern Thailand to survey the fuel biomass load on the forest floor. Concerns with biomass emissions and climate change had spawned a co-operative research project between King Mongkhut's University and the Forest Fire Control Centre of Chiang Mai (FFCC).</p><p>We were up at 3.30am and heading for FFCC. Here we transferred to a mini-bus and in association with my King Mongkhut's colleague, six Thai fire control officers and driver Dan, we headed southwest out of Chiang Mai. Our first stop was a large open food market where we bought breakfast. For 40 baht (a little more that one Aussie dollar), I staggered back to the minibus loaded down with mandarins, longans, sticky rice and sweet sausage, and most importantly a bottle of water (traditional spring water, UV treated and ozonised).</p><p>We circled southwest around Mt Inthanon, the highest mountain in Thailand at 2565m. We were soon travelling through lush mountain forest valleys and across ranges. There is a very dense cover of vegetation with bamboo clumps, a variety of trees and bushes, often covered with vines and creepers.</p><p>We pass through small villages full of mainly wooden houses with wooden shutters which can be propped open for air and light.</p><p>There are cleared valley floors planted with a wide variety of crops, rice, soybean, corn, bananas, coconuts, cabbages, pumpkins, garlic and more.</p><p>Pocket sized rice paddies are layered up the slopes.</p><p>Suddenly a police checkpoint blocks the road. Traffic slows and some get stopped and searched. Our government minibus is waved through. We turn north, more jungle.</p><p>Out of the jungle, a bandit appears with a rifle over his shoulder  or is it just a farmer with his trusty chipping hoe and my imagination getting carried away by the romance of this area?</p><p>My companions tell me there are 1864 curves between the town boundary of Chiang Mai and our destination but, by this time, I am trapped in the minibus. 300 kilometres on and I explore with Khun Or, the Head of the Thai group and Khun Ta, who, I think, speaks more English than she let's on, the possibility of a helicopter ride back to Chiang Mai. We all decide that it will be back to town by bus for all of us.</p><p>We have lunch in a small Thai open air cafe which is a thatched roof structure with tables and benches and no walls.</p><p>For 160 baht ($5.40), I buy lunch for nine people. Thais seem to like soup dishes, even in the heat; soup with noodles and various vegetables and meats. I settle for flat noodles and duck (mild spicy, kob khun crup), eaten with chop sticks.</p><p>With our tasks completed, we head home, passing a sign 'St Matthew's Catholic Church, and I wonder the origin of this church in this Buddhist domain.</p><p>Thais are generally a very tolerant race, friendly and kind to outsiders. There are many faces to Thailand  Amazing Thailand!</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:802S-JMW1-2RYX-12D6-00000-00Report says people should move from bushfire zones2010-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 1Report says people should move from bushfire zonesMilanda Rout

EXPERTS have called for a national debate on whether people have a right to live in deadly bushfire zones after a damning report from the Black Saturday royal commission argued against the rebuilding of some communities.

The commission's final report rejects the Victorian government's policy to rebuild all bushfire affected towns ``brick by brick'', saying some parts of the destroyed areas are too dangerous to re-inhabit and cannot be protected.

The commission -- chaired by Bernard Teague -- challenges the Brumby government to offer to buy out properties in areas deemed at ``unacceptably high bushfire risk'', saying the government should help people move away under a non-compulsory land acquisition program.

The controversial recommendation is one of 67 made by the commission in its final report, which severely criticises the performance of former Country Fire Authority chief Russell Rees, former police chief Christine Nixon and the fire chief of the Department of Sustainability and Resources, Ewan Waller.

The report -- which is more than 900 pages long and follows more than 15 months of hearings -- calls for sweeping changes in the way the fire agencies are run, the establishment of an overarching fire commissioner and the replacement of old electricity lines with bundled or underground cables.

Marysville family Peter and Rhyl Cobb and their children Maya and Tarni, who decided to rebuild their home after Black Saturday, were among many people in the town who were sceptical about the commission's recommendation to move people out of high bushfire areas.

``I think Marysville has a future, but it's going to take a long time,'' Ms Cobb said.

The commission, which cost taxpayers $37 million, also recommends that prescribed burning be tripled to 5 per cent of public land, the controversial ``stay or go'' policy be overhauled and more fire refuges be built in communities at risk of bushfires.

Premier John Brumby and his cabinet met yesterday afternoon

Continued on Page 4

Continued from Page 1

to formulate his government's ``interim'' response to the recommendations that will be released to the public this week.

It is understood the number of homes in need of possible resettlement, under the commission's criteria, could run into the tens of thousands and cost the Brumby government billions of dollars to buy back in areas such as the Dandenong Ranges and the Otway Ranges.

It is expected Mr Brumby will seek community input on contentious findings about resettlement, power lines and fuel reduction before making the final decision on what measures to adopt.

Mr Brumby, who also met Julia Gillard to brief her on the report, continued to back his besieged former and current emergency service leaders but he did publicly apologise for the failures on February 7.

The Victorian opposition pledged that it would implement every one of the commission's recommendations, including voluntary resettlement measures. ``I am committed to getting on with the job, implementing the royal commission's recommendations and speeding up the pace of reconstruction,'' said Opposition Leader Ted Baillieu.

Demographer Bob Birrell said the issue of whether people should live in extremely high-risk bushfire areas needed to be debated. He said it was a problem that was getting worse as the country's population increased, the urban metropolis expanded and more people were living in areas that backed on to the bush.

``This is one of the dilemmas of the urban sprawl,'' Dr Birrell said.

Former forest fire chief Athol Hodgson agreed. ``There are some areas that should not be developed and planning permits should not be granted,'' he said. He said proposed buyback of high bushfire-risk land was not new as it was implemented after fires in the 1960s and Ash Wednesday.

But Mr Hodgson said it had a limited take-up by government as affecting people's rights to decide where they lived was a controversial political issue.

The commission finds the Brumby government's pledge to rebuild every community ``brick by brick'' meant an opportunity was lost to rethink the long-term future of some communities.

``The commission understands the imperative to rebuild, but to rebuild without any real thought being given to the future management of bushfire risk is to fail to learn from experience,'' it states. The report also says the government should develop a ``retreat and resettlement strategy'' to ``help people move away from those areas where other bushfire mitigation measures are not viable''.

urn:contentItem:55BC-JHB1-F0J6-J4GV-00000-00Millions in peril as floodwaters rise2002-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 14Millions in peril as floodwaters riseMichael Dwyer BEIJING

China is facing its worst flooding since the late 1990s and more than 10million people are at risk as the country's second-largest lake threatens to burst its banks.

The Hunan provincial Government yesterday declared a state of emergency in response to the flooding, which has already lead to the deaths of more than 900 people over the past few weeks.

Authorities are still trying to estimate the financial cost of this year's flooding in central and southern China. Some reports suggest the final bill could be close to 45 billion yuan ($10 billion).

The most severe flooding has occurred in the area around the 2,800 square kilometre Lake Dongting in Hunan province. Close to 700,000 hectares of farmland are likely to be engulfed if it bursts it banks. Water levels in the lake have already climbed above the 32-metre flood warning mark, and meteorologists are predicting further heavy rain over the next few days.

More than 4,000 people died in 1998 when Lake Dongting which acts as a giant overflow for the Yangtze River last burst its banks.

Another 14 million people were left homeless as a result of the 1998 floods, the worst in China in more than 40 years.

"Officials are very worried about the situation," a spokeswoman for the International Red Cross told Agence France-Presse yesterday.

"The state of emergency means more workers will be mobilised, and some people will be moved from around the lake," she said.

The southern provinces of Guangdong and Guangxi are also now cleaning up after being battered by typhoon Vongfong, the 14th tropical storm to have hit the Chinese coast this year.

Flooding caused by Vongfong lead to the temporary closure of the main train line between Beijing and Kowloon.

China's official media also reported yesterday that 40 people were now confirmed dead as the result of a massive mudslide in the southern province of Yunnan last week. Authorities are now worried that more such events could occur as a result of continuing heavy rain.

Although southern China has been hit hard over recent weeks by monsoon rains, other parts of the country have been battling strong bushfires.

Earlier this week, Chinese officials said a forest fire that had been raging for 23 days in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region had finally been extinguished.

Heavy rains in other parts of Asia have also lead to significant death tolls.

More than 900 people have died in India, Nepal and Bangladesh since mid-July. Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam have also suffered as the result of unusually severe flooding.

Water levels of the Mekong River, in Vietnam, are reportedly at a 30-year high.

ILLUS: Flooded out ... a family cross a street in Chongqing, southern China, on a makeshift raft. Photo: AFP

urn:contentItem:802S-JMW1-2RYX-12M0-00000-00Report says people should move from bushfire zones2010-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 1Report says people should move from bushfire zonesMilanda Rout, Stuart Rintoul

EXPERTS have called for a national debate on whether people have a right to live in deadly bushfire zones after a damning report from the Black Saturday royal commission argued against the rebuilding of some communities.

The commission's final report rejects the Victorian government's policy to rebuild all bushfire affected towns ``brick by brick'', saying some parts of the destroyed areas are too dangerous to re-inhabit and cannot be protected.

The commission -- chaired by Bernard Teague -- challenges the Brumby government to offer to buy out properties in areas deemed at ``unacceptably high bushfire risk'', saying the government should help people move away under a non-compulsory land acquisition program.

The controversial recommendation is one of 67 made by the commission in its final report, which severely criticises the performance of former Country Fire Authority chief Russell Rees, former police chief Christine Nixon and the fire chief of the Department of Sustainability and Resources, Ewan Waller.

The report -- which is more than 900 pages long and follows more than 15 months of hearings -- calls for sweeping changes in the way the fire agencies are run, the establishment of an overarching fire commissioner and the replacement of old electricity lines with bundled or underground cables.

Marysville family Peter and Rhyl Cobb and their children Maya and Tarni, who decided to rebuild their home after Black Saturday, were among many people in the town who were sceptical about the commission's recommendation to move people out of high bushfire areas.

``I think Marysville has a future, but it's going to take a long time,'' Ms Cobb said.

The commission, which cost taxpayers $37 million, also recommends that prescribed burning be tripled to 5 per cent of public land, the controversial ``stay or go'' policy be overhauled and more fire refuges be built in communities at risk of bushfires.

Premier John Brumby and his cabinet met yesterday afternoon

Continued on Page 4

Continued from Page 1

to formulate his government's ``interim'' response to the recommendations that will be released to the public this week.

It is understood the number of homes in need of possible resettlement, under the commission's criteria, could run into the tens of thousands and cost the Brumby government billions of dollars to buy back in areas such as the Dandenong Ranges and the Otway Ranges.

It is expected Mr Brumby will seek community input on contentious findings about resettlement, power lines and fuel reduction before making the final decision on what measures to adopt.

Mr Brumby, who also met Julia Gillard to brief her on the report, continued to back his besieged former and current emergency service leaders but he did publicly apologise for the failures on February 7.

The Victorian opposition pledged that it would implement every one of the commission's recommendations, including voluntary resettlement measures. ``I am committed to getting on with the job, implementing the royal commission's recommendations and speeding up the pace of reconstruction,'' said Opposition Leader Ted Baillieu.

Demographer Bob Birrell said the issue of whether people should live in extremely high-risk bushfire areas needed to be debated. He said it was a problem that was getting worse as the country's population increased, the urban metropolis expanded and more people were living in areas that backed on to the bush.

``This is one of the dilemmas of the urban sprawl,'' Dr Birrell said.

Former forest fire chief Athol Hodgson agreed. ``There are some areas that should not be developed and planning permits should not be granted,'' he said. He said proposed buyback of high bushfire-risk land was not new as it was implemented after fires in the 1960s and Ash Wednesday.

But Mr Hodgson said it had a limited take-up by government as affecting people's rights to decide where they lived was a controversial political issue.

The commission finds the Brumby government's pledge to rebuild every community ``brick by brick'' meant an opportunity was lost to rethink the long-term future of some communities.

``The commission understands the imperative to rebuild, but to rebuild without any real thought being given to the future management of bushfire risk is to fail to learn from experience,'' it states. The report says the government should develop a ``retreat and resettlement strategy'' to ``help people move away from those areas where other bushfire mitigation measures are not viable''.

urn:contentItem:4GBV-T970-015G-T3J4-00000-00<published>2005-06-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>ED; Pg. 20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Herald Sun  EDITORIAL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Guarding the gate</p><p nitf:lede="true">KNEE-jerk reaction or not, the Federal Government's security crackdown at our airports and on the wharves is both overdue and welcome.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Disturbing allegations of serious crime at Australia's entry and exit points have been raised -- in particular, drug smuggling by some airport baggage handlers.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Thus an embarrassed Government has become both alert and alarmed and forced to do what it should have done long ago.</p><p>Deputy Prime Minister John Anderson says any of the 200,000 workers at the airports and docks who has what he quaintly describes as a "murky past" will be removed from the job.</p><p>Few would disagree with Mr Anderson's view that our airports need a robust and permanent security presence. The wonder is that he is saying so four years after September 11 changed the world forever.</p><p>One way of making the security presence "robust" would be to end the ridiculous demarcation of powers between law officers at the nation's international airports.</p><p>At present the Australian Protective Service officers have first response powers in the event of a terrorist attack, but can't arrest suspects or trouble makers. Absurdly, they must call in the local police.</p><p>Through such administrative cracks terrorists and criminals can slip.</p><p>Faith in the flag</p><p>THE Uniting Church's denigration of the Australian flag is deplorable.</p><p>A church discussion paper says the flag could be seen as a symbol of oppression and injustice by detained asylum-seekers.</p><p>Worse, the paper suggests that Christians disenchanted with the world wars and Korea and Vietnam or Iraq might not regard the flag as a Christian symbol.</p><p>The paper follows a church minister's refusal to allow a World War II veteran to have a flag on his casket in the church.</p><p>The discussion paper now advises ministers they can allow flags on caskets but urges them to hold RSL services outside the church where possible.</p><p>The RSL rightly points out people died under the flag for the religious freedoms that Australians enjoy today.</p><p>The church should beware, lest its lack of faith in the flag leads to empty pews.</p><p>Burning questions</p><p>AN independent report on the Wilsons Promontory burn-off debacle points to what its authors see as serious errors. The authors are two firefighting experts, members of Forest Fire Victoria.</p><p>The report says that before the burn-off escaped, the authorities failed to patrol it effectively. It burned 6000ha.</p><p>The experts say that before the burn-off, up to 220 seasonal firefighters were sacked by the State Government to save money.</p><p>When the temperature rose and the fire escaped, the Department of the Environment and Sustainability tried unsuccessfully to rehire the firefighters.</p><p>One of the report's authors said that to reduce the number of seasonal firefighters when the DSE was involved in autumn burn-offs seemed utter nonsense.</p><p>The other suggested merging Parks Victoria, DSE and VicForests into one authority to manage forests and bushfires.</p><p>The report has no official status, but its views are those of expert firefighters. They must be heeded.</p><p>DEATHS ON OUR ROADS</p><p>THIS YEAR 164</p><p>LAST YEAR 165</p><p>Victorian deaths in 2005, compared with the same day last year.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459P-SWX0-0197-V170-00000-00<published>1997-12-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dispelling bushfire myths</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MISINFORMATION and myth can cost firefighters and the community</p><p nitf:lede="true">dearly, says CSIRO's Phil Cheney.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In a new book, Grassfires: Fuel, Weather and Fire Behaviour, CSIRO's</p><p nitf:lede="true">top bushfire scientists explain how a knowledge of grassfire behaviour</p><p nitf:lede="true">under the prevailing fuel and weather conditions can help reduce the</p><p nitf:lede="true">danger to firefighters and property damage.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Grassfires cause millions of dollars of damage each year in grazing</p><p nitf:lede="true">and pastoral lands across Australia. Under extreme conditions they can</p><p>spread at speeds in excess of 20 km/h, threaten homes and lives and</p><p>cause untold damage to fencing, crops and stock.</p><p>Grassfires covers all aspects of fire behaviour in the common</p><p>grassland fuels, including spinifex, of Australia. The influence of</p><p>fuel, weather and topography on fire spread are discussed in the</p><p>context of firefighter safety and wildfire suppression tactics and</p><p>strategies.</p><p>Case histories of several major wildfires that have caused significant</p><p>loss of life and property damage in pastoral areas are used to</p><p>illustrate grassfire behaviour under extreme conditions.</p><p>"We wrote the book for the volunteer bushfire brigades," senior</p><p>author Phil Cheney said. "These people, and rural landholders with</p><p>assets at stake each summer, need good information on how fires behave</p><p>to plan property protection and fire suppression.</p><p>"The chapter on the myths, facts and fallacies will help explain the</p><p>unusual fire behaviour that makes bushfires so mysterious and</p><p>frightening to some people."</p><p>The book grew out of research conducted in the Northern Territory in</p><p>1986. Over 120 experimental fires were lit in varying fuel and weather</p><p>conditions during the dry season.</p><p>"It took close to 10 years to analyse all the data we gathered," Mr</p><p>Cheney said.</p><p>"We found that some of the long-held beliefs of grassfire spread and</p><p>behaviour were incorrect. New fire spread prediction meters _ slide</p><p>rules which estimate how fast a grassfire will spread _ were developed</p><p>to incorporate the new information that we had learned."</p><p>"It is 30 years since the last detailed publication in Australia of</p><p>grassfire behaviour knowledge," co-author Andrew Sullivan said.</p><p>"In that time our understanding of the factors that influence</p><p>grassfire behaviour _ fuel, weather, terrain _ and the interaction</p><p>between them has advanced considerably."</p><p>Work to improve our knowledge of forest fire behaviour is currently</p><p>being conducted by CSIRO in collaboration with the Western Australian</p><p>Department of Conservation and Land Management. The project is</p><p>expected to be completed within five years.</p><p>Grassfires: Fuel, Weather and Fire Behaviour is and available from</p><p>CSIRO, phone (03) 9662 7666, fax (03) 9662-7555 or at all Government</p><p>bookshops for $24.95.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P89-SSP0-TXN5-T21Y-00000-00Firefighters fear summer inferno1997-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Firefighters fear summer infernoForest battle sparks warningLISA TAIT Staff Reporter

A BUSHFIRE that burnt through 350ha of the Medowie State Forest for three days has firefighters fearing the worst for this year's fire season in the Hunter Region.

The Port Stephens fire control officer, Mr Allan Hepplewhite, believes the weather conditions are right for a season as bad as the 1991 bushfires.

Fire officers were on alert yesterday as they battled the Medowie fire and another near Fassifern, which burnt through 400ha of bush.

Mr Hepplewhite said he was concerned about the dry conditions and carelessness.

`People have got to be alert if they see people going into the bush and acting suspiciously,' he said.

`There is the potential there for people to lose their lives.'

No property was damaged in the State Forest fire but smoke spread as far as Newcastle on Saturday. State Forest officers spent 72 hours containing the fire before it was brought under control around 5pm.

Mr Hepplewhite said the fire almost certainly had been lit deliberately.

The weather conditions made it difficult for officers to contain the fire.

It was contained in an area bounded by James and Taylors roads, Medowie.

Fire units struggled for several hours yesterday to contain the Fassifern fire.

It started at 11.51am and became worse throughout the day.

Fire officers struggled with the dry and windy conditions, which turned the flames towards nearby houses.

Backburning then turned the fire away from the houses.

The fire was brought under control late yesterday afternoon by three NSW Fire Brigade and several Bush Fire Brigade units.

It followed fears that the El Nino effect could have severe implications for Hunter Valley fire officers this season.

Hunter fire officers said they held concerns for the summer bushfire season, after the weekend's spate of bushfires.

While brigades were keeping fires under control yesterday in the Wallsend/Morisset area, there were concerns that a westerly wind would cause major problems.

`It's the start of the summer period and if it stays dry, we could be in for a bad time after Christmas,' a fire brigade officer said.

Officers used backburning and water tankers to contain the Fassifern fire.

At one stage the fire jumped past officers and they were forced to regroup into another position.

Officers reported a number of bush areas alight in the region at the weekend, including most of the bush lining the freeway from Wallsend to Morisset.

urn:contentItem:5388-74K1-JCVT-J206-00000-00Dark themes in a new light2011-07-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENT GUIDEMusicPg. 7Dark themes in a new lightAnnabel Ross

Foster the People mix sunny tunes with stormy subjects, writes Annabel Ross. LISTEN closely to the lyrics of Foster the People's Pumped Up Kicks and you'll find a story at odds with the falsetto chorus and wistful whistles. "All the other kids with the pumped up kicks/you'd better run, better run, outrun my gun/All the other kids with the pumped up kicks/you'd better run, better run, faster than my bullet." The owner of the gun in question is Robert, a "cowboy kid" with "a quick hand"; singer-lyricist Mark Foster says the song is something of a homage to Truman Capote's In Cold Blood; in his meditation on the disaffectedness of youth, Foster wanted to get inside the head of his child-killer protagonist.

Juxtaposing dark ideas with sunny music is a recurring theme on FTP's debut album, Torches. "It's not a dark record overall lyrically," says Foster on the phone from London, where the band are on their first European tour. "But there's a nice mixture of darker subject matter ... that's how life is, there are peaks and valleys in life and that's how I like to write songs." Foster, 27, knows all about peaks and valleys. The Cleveland, Ohio, native has lived in Los Angeles for the past nine years. Eight were spent telemarketing and delivering pizza, "doing the whole struggling artist thing". He followed the bright lights on the advice of his father. "I wanted to be an attorney all the way up until I was 17," Foster says. "I didn't know what I wanted to do. I had really bad grades in high school and didn't want to go to college and my dad said, 'Why don't you move to LA or New York and pursue music? You've always been good at it.' It was the first thing that made sense to me and ... It was the right move." The album, which comes with the obligatory buzz surrounding the band's potential to fill the shoes left by MGMT, is pleasingly diverse. "The record is pretty eclectic - it's very versatile but also cohesive," Foster says. "There are elements that are very electronic, there are elements of more classic songwriting with more bass, drum, piano and guitar. That's the type of songwriter I am. I don't like to write the same song twice." Foster's Beach Boys influences are worn proudly and, though it's impossible to shake references to contemporaries such as Phoenix and Peter Bjorn and John, FTP's sound is unmistakably Californian. Torches has a dual meaning for Foster. "A lot of the songs are about shedding old skin and coming into something new and I think that's a theme about how our lives have changed over the past year," he says. "We've all worked really hard to try to stay afloat in LA for years and now things are going really well for us. Torches is ... a representation of fire and it can burn things down but it can also light the path." The last date on their sell-out US tour was at California's Coachella festival in April, providing their first bona fide rock-star moment. "We went from playing to crowds of 200 to 600 people in clubs for about 5Â½ weeks right into playing Coachella," Foster says. "We walked out on to that stage and as far as the eye could see, there were people there to see us play. That's surreal but it was awesome ... 10,000 people singing Pumped Up Kicks back at me." Foster's humility comes through in the interview, from tales of the early days singing in front of seven or eight people at open-mike nights to excited celebrity spotting - Steve Carell, Shia LaBeouf - at his gigs. He's clearly most proud that, pre-FTP's success, he met Rivers Cuomo from Weezer in LA, who taught him to play Say It Ain't So on guitar. Most revealing is what I overhear Foster say to the telephone operator after our chat. "Can you get that guy back on the line, the one from two or three interviews back?" he says. "He didn't get much time and I felt like there was more he wanted to ask me. Besides, I liked talking to him." Foster wants to extend the same graciousness in Berlin to the German girl whose blog post of Pumped Up Kicks last year "was the spark that started the forest fire" when it was picked up by music blog aggregator the Hype Machine. "We're going to Berlin next week, so we should drop her a note so we can meet up and grab a drink or something." Torches is out through Sony. FTP play Splendour in the Grass, July 29-31, and the Hi-Fi, city, July 27.

urn:contentItem:57MX-HT61-JD6R-T0MP-00000-00Fires, floods, and why it's not all bad news in 20132013-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisFires, floods, and why it's not all bad news in 2013Peter JohnsonABSTRACT

While Australia has copped fires and floods this summer, fire expert Peter Johnson points out there have been relatively few deaths from natural disasters. He examines why.

FULL TEXT

Along the east coast of Australia, the top half is underwater and the bottom half has seen major bushfires in the past month. It's remarkable more people haven't died.

Could it be that the authorities are becoming more effective at emergency management? Or are people responding better to the multiple layers of warnings now in place, particularly since the terrible 2009 Victorian bushfires of Black Saturday, or the frightening Brisbane floods of 2011?

The answer is we probably don't know, and will not know unless we do the necessary research and collect the evidence. Let's do the research. Then we can look at collecting the evidence.

There appears to be some indication that fewer lives have been lost this season (at least in the bushfires of this past month) because the conditions have not been as extreme.

In the case of bushfires this 2012-13 season, Victoria has experienced few days where circumstances have been judged to be "extreme", and no days have been declared "code red" or "catastrophic" with the Forest Fire Danger Index over 100. On Black Saturday, the FFDI was judged to be between 120 and 200 in some areas, and 173 lives were lost. This season there have been some major fires, such as the Aberfeldy-Donnellys fire which burned nearly 70,000 hectares, with no multiple casualties.

The conditions, at least in Victoria, appear to have been such that the emergency services have been able to give warnings in sufficient time for most people to respond and evacuate, or prepare to defend their property themselves. In Tasmania, the major fire at Dunalley in early January was judged to be "catastrophic" at times by Fire Chief Mike Brown, however no lives were lost and perhaps conditions were not as severe as first thought. One firefighter died, but of natural causes.

While suggesting this year's bushfire conditions down the east coast (excluding Tasmania) have generally not been as severe as they may appear from media reports, a degree of success may be attributed to new forms of warning and more effective responses of individuals and communities to imminent life-threatening conditions.

In the case of floods in Queensland and NSW in particular, conditions have been catastrophic, especially in places like Bundaberg where wholesale evacuations have been required. While there have been a small number of people who have perished, the dangers of floodwaters at time still seem to go unheeded.

When natural disasters strike, there are warnings provided on ABC radio and fire authority websites. More official channels are now supplemented in some areas by new emergency warning systems, including use of Twitter and Facebook, the CFA Fire Ready App in Victoria, and the Emergency Alert SMS messaging systems. On the other hand, the evidence presented at the Victoria Bushfire Royal Commission was that many people got their warnings from simple observations of fire or smoke approaching, or from neighbours via a phone call. The same is probably true of floods.

It may well be that rather than responding to official warnings from government authorities, many people may now be getting their warnings via social media or through person-to-person communications. If that is the case, then the whole approach to emergency management and development of more resilient communities may need even greater focus on social media.

However, a recent report in the Herald Sun highlights the issue of "hoaxes and false rumours spread through social media by trolls and misinformed internet users". This has the potential to destroy the trust so important to effective warning systems which was highlighted by Melbourne University's John Handmer at the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission (see the "warning" chapter).

So, has emergency management and communities' response to bushfires and floods improved over the last three years, especially in this January 2013 period? Or have conditions been generally less severe, particularly in the bushfire case? To repeat an earlier comment: the answer is we probably don't know, and will not know unless we do the necessary research and collect the evidence.

Let's look at collecting the evidence, or data. Fire authorities and emergency services will probably conduct normal debriefs at the end of the fire season. During the post-flood recovery period, there will be reviews conducted, to try and uncover the lessons learnt. However this needs good, consistent year-on-year research, good incident data collect and analysis and real testing of evidence on effective emergency management.

The Bushfire Co-Operative Research Centre is nearing the end of its projected life. The Fire Protection Association Australia is calling for a national body to at least manage fire incident data, analysis and research from which regulators, emergency managers, insurers, community leaders and the public can make better informed decisions to improve public safety and address the questions posed at the outset - have we done better this year on emergency management, with improved community response? Or have we just been fortunate that conditions have been less severe than previous years?

It would be helpful to know the answers, and a national body that collects and analyses data could well be a step to finding these answers and better informing design and policy.

*Peter Johnson is a senior member of the fire engineering practice at Arup, an independent firm of designers, planners, engineers, consultants and technical specialists

urn:contentItem:459F-XMR0-0197-T4H1-00000-00<published>1997-09-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>El Nino empties food bowl</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>RUFFINI PAUL</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE once-lush Tambul Valley in Papua New Guinea's Western Highlands is normally considered a food bowl, but now 11,000 villagers are facing starvation.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Even if rain comes to the parched hills within a month, it may not be enough to save them.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The mountain farmers who usually produce kaukau (sweet potatoes), cabbages, carrots and potatoes in abundance have nowhere to go.</p><p>Famine blamed on the El Nino weather effect surrounds them _ at Kandep to the west, Mendi to the south and the Hagen region to the east.</p><p>In previous hard times they have migrated to neighbouring provinces and survived on handouts from family and friends _ this time they have no choice.</p><p>"The only situation left for the people is to starve to death," farmer Martin Bai said as he examined his bare garden.</p><p>"Areas where we normally migrate to are also affected now, like Hagen, Wabag and Mendi." The Tambul-Nebiliyer region tucked in the Western Highlands' south-west is one of the areas hardest hit by the nationwide drought.</p><p>Continuing frosts have meant double trouble for the highlanders, killing what's left of their drought-ravaged crops.</p><p>The shrubs, casuarinas, firs and banana trees that cover the mountains around Tambul are drying to a copper colour.</p><p>A smoke haze blots out the sun as a massive forest fire sweeps up from Mt Giluwe to the south and smaller blazes rage through the mountains.</p><p>Rivers like Amboga near Tambul village have fallen 2m over the past four months. Mountain streams, usually the source of water for drinking and cooking, are running at a trickle.</p><p>The black soil of the food gardens is bare except for small patches of frost-burned cabbage and withered kaukau plants.</p><p>District administrator Douglas Lingawa remembers the last major drought in 1972, when Australia came to the rescue of the villagers by air-dropping sacks of rice and cartons of tinned food.</p><p>Mr Lingawa said the drought was the worst in 50 years. There was no starvation yet, but food would not last much longer.</p><p>The Papua New Guinea Government has contributed $A22.8 million to relief nationwide.</p><p>Mr Lingawa is already seeing the drought's social impact. Thirty schools in the Tambul-Nebiliyer region have closed due to lack of water.</p><p>Although there have been no deaths directly attributable to the situation, dysentery and typhoid have increased, particularly among children.</p><p>Farmer Bai said that even if rain came within the next two months it would be a year before the sweet potato crop, the staple food source, was re-established.</p><p>AAP</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5HSW-8F01-JD67-12YR-00000-00Get ready for more extreme fires2009-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisAGRIBUSINESSGet ready for more extreme firesMEX COOPER & MARIKA DOBBIN

Victorians are bracing themselves for further bushfires tomorrow with forecast extreme weather again putting homes and lives at high risk.

Friday has been labelled "spike day" when the Forest Fire Danger Index is set to climb with temperatures predicted to reach as high as 40 degrees in the north of the state coupled with north-westerly winds.

A strong south-westerly wind change is expected to sweep through in the afternoon and early evening and possible thunderstorms could bring lightning strikes.

Parks Victoria has warned visitors to avoid bush and parklands with national parks in high-risk areas closed to the public.

Bureau of Meteorology duty forecaster Richard Russell said the weather conditions would be similar to Monday when fires flared in outer Melbourne.

But the temperatures would be about 10 degrees lower than those experienced on Black Saturday and the winds half to two-thirds as powerful.

Mr Russell said the Bureau had downgraded the city's top temperature from 38 to 36 degrees and the south and south-west of the state was now not expected to reach higher than the mid 30s.

But the in the Mallee the mercury could still touch 40 degrees.

Fire expert and ecologist Kevin Tolhurst said the fire index, that ranges from zero to 100, would be about 50-70 in central Victoria.

In the days leading up to Black Saturday it reached above 200.

However, unlike Feburary 7 when only the Bunyip Ridge fire was burning, Mr Tolhurst said there were now four uncontrolled fires still blazing in Victoria.

Exhausted crews will be forced to battle tomorrow's forecast winds and heat to keep the state's bushfires behind borders that now total 1100 kilometres - the distance from Melbourne's CBD to Mildura and back.

Additional reinforcements from New Zealand, Western Australia and NSW will arrive today and tomorrow to help almost 4500 firefighters patrol the massive stretches of fire edge on what is predicted to be another hellish day.

Department of Sustainability and Environment chief fire officer Ewan Waller said, in addition to the going fires, he expected new fires would start tomorrow, and old ones would reignite.

He said the 1.4 millimetres of rain that fell in Melbourne yesterday did nothing to calm the fires. In fact, it prevented backburning and made the terrain more difficult for fire vehicles.

"The rain is light and, in fact, will be more of a hindrance than a help. It's only coastal so it won't impact on the areas we want it to impact on," he said.

An extra 50 New Zealand, 21 WA and 110 NSW Parks firefighters have been called in to add to the 1121 interstate and overseas personnel.

A South Australian Country Fire Service volunteer yesterday became the fourth interstater to be injured by a falling tree, in addition to the death of Canberra firefighter David Balfour last week, when he was working to contain fires near Alexandra, about 60 kilometres north-east of Melbourne.

The 39-year-old received head injuries and was last night in the Royal Melbourne Hospital in a stable condition.

Mr Waller said fire crews working in the recovery effort would be recalled to the fire front in preparation for tomorrow.

The fires at Won Wron in Gippsland, Bunyip State Park, Kilmore East-Murrindindi, Muskvale near Daylesford and Upwey in Melbourne's outer east are of particular concern.

Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin said people in fire-affected areas should decide now to leave before tomorrow or be physically and mentally prepared to defend their properties.

"Our message is very clear. Friday is expected and forecast to be a very bad day," he said "We need that message to be heard by the whole Victoria community ... We need everybody to be on their guard."

CFA chief Russell Rees said the bushfires on Monday, which added another 160 kilometres to the combined fire edge, were a stark warning the emergency was not over.

"There's only one or two pockets of Victoria which haven't had major fires this summer. The whole state is dry and the whole state is at risk," he said.
