urn:contentItem:4G1W-W840-015H-H1T8-00000-00<published>2005-04-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>TELEVISION; Pg. 18</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>TV GUIDE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WHAT'S ON</p><p nitf:lede="true">TUESDAY</p><p nitf:lede="true">THE gang go to Palm Springs for a parent-free weekend in The OC on Imparja at 11.15pm tonight.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Ryan, Seth, Marissa, Anna, Luke and Summer stay at the home of Marissa's new, troubled friend Oliver.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Ryan agrees to make the road trip with Luke in the hope of spending time alone with Marissa.</p><p>Oliver quickly irritates Ryan by flirting with Marissa and deliberately keeping the couple apart. Summer uses every method she can to annoy Seth and Anna.</p><p>WHAT'S ON</p><p>WEDNESDAY</p><p>THE final episode of dark British comedy Nighty Night airs on ABC at 9pm.</p><p>Terry survives cancer but finds himself confined to a locked room of his home.</p><p>Apart from the inconvenience of having told everyone he is dead, Jill has not forgiven him for an affair with her assistant.</p><p>She moves in with Glen to get her hands on his bank balance.</p><p>When the vicar disturbs their love-nest, she finds a sweet solution to all of her problems.</p><p>WHAT'S ON</p><p>THURSDAY</p><p>THE Best of Storyline Australia: Becoming Julia is about a likeable Australian man and how he became the woman of his dreams.</p><p>Affable bus driver Paul grew up in Bathurst and is a diehard rev-head.</p><p>Paul feels like a woman trapped in a man's body, and this intimate documentary follows him for two years through his decision to live as a woman.</p><p>Paul has gender re-assignment surgery and becomes Julia.</p><p>WHAT'S ON</p><p>FRIDAY</p><p>WORLD Weddings -- Mohammad and the Matchmakers looks at four different couples about to get married.</p><p>The first of the four-part BBC documentary series follows 47-year-old Mohammad and young widow Maryam's search for love.</p><p>They are HIV positive -- part of a growing crisis in Iran because of widespread drug use.</p><p>Arash Alaie is acting as an unlikely matchmaker for HIV positive patients.</p><p>The program starts on SBS at 7pm.</p><p>WHAT'S ON</p><p>SATURDAY</p><p>TOM Cruise and Nicole Kidman star in racing movie Days of Thunder on Imparja at 10pm.</p><p>Pulses raced on and off-the-track as Cruise and Kidman fell in love on the film set.</p><p>The story centres around Cole Trickle (Cruise), who enters the high-pressure world of Nascar racing.</p><p>He is a hot driver with a hot temper.</p><p>Trickle's attitude gets him into trouble with other drivers and members of his own team. The film also stars Robert Duvall.</p><p>WHAT'S ON</p><p>SUNDAY</p><p>IMPARJA is screening a night of glitz and glamour with the 47th annual TV Week Logie Awards.</p><p>Viewers will see all the fashion on the new white carpet when Australia's biggest television names dazzle in designer creations from 7.30pm.</p><p>The star-studded awards, hosted by Eddie McGuire, Rove McManus and Andrew O'Keefe, will honour the achievements of the most popular programs and the stars.</p><p>The Logies ceremony starts at 8.15mp.</p><p>WHAT'S ON</p><p>MONDAY</p><p>MYTHBUSTERS investigates bizarre claims of urban legends and modern misconceptions on SBS at 7pm.</p><p>This week, Adam and Jamie ask: Can a scuba diver be sucked from the water by a fire-fighting helicopter and get spat out or dropped in the middle of a forest fire?</p><p>They attempt to solve this puzzling question.</p><p>And just to see what happens, they fire a bullet at a petrol tank, shove a banana in a car's exhaust pipe and put sugar in a petrol tank.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7V2T-WC50-YB64-44YR-00000-00Grief collapses into the loving arms of families who understand the pain2009-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 5Grief collapses into the loving arms of families who understand the painSHOW OF UNITY - DAY OF MOURNINGGeoff Strong and Paul Austin

LEXIE REID cradled her daughter Maureen, still coming to terms with her grief, in the Monash University auditorium at Churchill yesterday as they took part in a national show of sympathy for a loss that was very much their own.

That loss was a son and a grandson who had left the safety of the family home in Traralgon on Saturday, February 7, to help some friends in the nearby town of Koornalla defend their home. Nathan Charles, 21, and three of the family he had gone to help perished in the blaze.

And even while the country mourned, Victoria's bushfire emergency was far from over. Friday looms as extremely dangerous, and people in the Warburton and Yarra valleys could come under threat today.

The Reids were among about 200 at the auditorium to watch a video transmission of the National Day of Mourning memorial service in Melbourne. Some wept, others clung to each other during the service.

It was cool yesterday, but through the auditorium windows the tops of the Strzelecki Ranges to the south were black and ominously close to town.

Nearby Callignee is in ruins, Hazelwood was hit hard, and the first Strzelecki town to succumb to bushfire, Delburn, has been somewhat forgotten in the disaster that followed.

Maureen Reid was too distraught to talk, but her mother said she felt the service soothed some of the pain. "The music and speeches and support really helped, but I still don't know how to put my feelings into words. It is still so hard."

Another family, the Kincaids, lost all but their pets. Jody, Robert and their two children had lived for six years in a 100-year-old timber home in the Callignee Ridge area.

"We are lucky we have been able to stay with friends in Traralgon, along with our pets," Mrs Kincaid said. "That family also does foster care. They threw their doors open to us. But to give them some relief DHS [the Department of Human Services] has found us somewhere over the weekend."

The family has not been deterred by the disaster and plans to return to the land they love. "Someone has just given us a 31-foot caravan and the local CFA [Country Fire Authority] has put on showers and toilets. We are moving back on Tuesday."

Fire chiefs are warning residents in at-risk areas that if they plan to leave rather than stay to defend their properties, they should leave early today.

A CFA state duty officer, Neil Bumpstead, said residents would be most at risk after a wind change forecast for late this afternoon. He said that if fire reached the Warburton Valley, those who left would need to stay away for several days. "We cannot stress enough that with limited road access in the Warburton Valley, traffic may become congested. Being on the roads is dangerous during a fire threat."

The Enoch Point area, near Gaffneys Creek and south of Eildon, was of particular concern, with winds expected to turn north and north-westerly today at speeds of 20 to 30 kmh.

A state duty officer at the Department of Sustainability and Environment, Andrew Graystone, said extreme forest fire danger had been forecast in the Mallee and a very high forest and grassland fire danger was forecast across the state, with the exception of East Gippsland.

The CFA declared today a day of total fire ban in the north-western, north-eastern, eastern and central districts.

The Premier, John Brumby, urged people in fire-prone parts of the state to implement their fire survival plans.

He said no Victorian should need to be reminded that the state was very dry after a drought lasting many years and then the baking heat of recent weeks. "It doesn't need much to make them [fires] run," he said.

Concerned about a rift between the CFA and the firefighters' union over services on Black Saturday, Mr Brumby called for an end to finger pointing.

"I don't know of any firefighter who didn't do their best," he said.

PHOTO: Lexie Reid with her daughter, Maureen. Photo: Sebastian Costanzo

urn:contentItem:457Y-MGS0-0197-553G-00000-00<published>1997-09-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Call to evacuate city as haze thickens</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">INDONESIAN Environment Minister Sarwono Kusumaatmadja has recommended Rengat city, with a population of 50,000 people, be evacuated immediately due to worsening smog.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mr Kusumaatmadja said the air quality and visibility had become so bad he would ask the national co-ordinating board for disaster mitigation to evacuate the city in Riau province, Central Sumatra, "right away". "We haven't had any reports of wide-scale migration, but in this kind of situation we have to assume that it is going to happen," Mr Kusumaatmadja said after the second day of the Association of South-East Asian Nations' ministerial meeting on the environment.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP</p></bodyText></section><p>The minister said he had been operating in "crisis mode" for the past five months trying to find solutions to the widening forest fire crisis and the dense smoke that has enveloped parts of Indonesia and its neighbours.</p><p> The health-threatening haze also shrouds most of Malaysia. A Muslim fundamentalist leader was quoted yesterday as saying it was God's punishment to his people for ignoring him.</p><p> Nik Aziz Nik Mat, chief minister of the north-east State of Kelantan -the country's sole Opposition-led State said God was also angry for the "vice the people have committed", the daily Star newspaper said.</p><p> "It has been stated that a time will come when the sky will emit such thick smoke and that the people will appeal to God to make it disappear," Mr Nik Aziz was quoted as saying.</p><p> "Thank God, here in Kelantan, the situation is not as bad as in other States. Maybe it is because the wind blows the haze away," he added.</p><p>Malaysian Opposition leader Lim Kit Siang said yesterday a public apology by Indonesian President Suharto for the severe regional pollution was not enough.</p><p> Mr Lim called for joint efforts by ASEAN to stop the forest fires in Sumatra and Kalimantan.</p><p> "Suharto's apology is inadequate unless Indonesia is prepared to allow an ASEAN Haze Committee to have full powers to stop the raging forest fires in Indonesia which are choking Malaysia and neighbouring countries," he said.</p><p> Mr Suharto issued the apology in a speech on Tuesday to the ASEAN environment conference.</p><p>Singapore and Malaysia have been blanketed by a smoky haze for weeks, causing health and navigation problems. Pollution has hit hazardous  levels in greater Kuala Lumpur.</p><p> Mr Lim said Mr Suharto's apology was gracious and marked the first time the Indonesian Government "has shown responsibility for causing the haze crisis faced by her neighbouring countries".</p><p>AFP</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459F-XMM0-0197-T3PN-00000-00<published>1997-09-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Place for Sinn Fein assured SINN Fein, the IRA's political wing, has signed a declaration renouncing violence, assuring itself of a place at historic Northern Ireland peace talks next week. "I think that it is a defining moment," president Gerry Adams said at the government building in Belfast where the all-party talks are due to start on Monday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Blaze threatens Inca ruins A HUGE forest fire raged out of control around Peru's Inca citadel of Machu Picchu yesterday as intense heat and huge palls of smoke frustrated the efforts of hundreds of firefighters. The fire devoured 600ha of dense vegetation and came within 200m of the ruins. The area was blocked to visitors to Peru's most popular tourist site, 3000m above sea level.</p><p>Mother Teresa draws 75,000 ABOUT 75,000 people filed past Mother Teresa's body on Tuesday night as the church holding it stayed open for mourners to pay their last respects to the "Saint of the Gutters". Hundreds, many cradling children, waited in queues outside. The funeral for Mother Teresa, who died on Friday after a cardiac arrest, will be on Saturday.</p><p>Bluefin tuna on the brink THE Southern Ocean bluefin tuna, one of the world's largest fishes, faced extinction from intensive fishing, Greenpeace said yesterday.</p><p>"This is a dire warning from scientists," Greenpeace ocean co-ordinator Desley Mather said. "Despite an up to 98% decline in southern bluefin tuna since the 1950s, there is actually pressure to increase the catch. If current fishing levels are maintained, this fish will probably disappear within one generation, or around the year 2020." Bridge Too Far survivor dies AUSTRALIAN-born General Sir John Hackett, the last surviving senior British officer from the infamous Bridge Too Far Battle of Arnhem, died yesterday, aged 86. Hackett, who became commander-in-chief of the British Army of the Rhine, died at his Gloucestershire home. After leaving the British Army in 1968, he became the principal of King's College, London, and wrote several books, including The Third World War.</p><p>Tiger boat raid sparks clash TAMIL Tiger rebel gunboats attacked and set ablaze a Hong Kong-owned cargo ship anchored off north-eastern Sri Lanka yesterday. At least 32 people were killed in the fighting. Two Sri Lankan soldiers guarding the freighter and five civilian labourers died in the ship assault, the Government said, and 25 guerillas were killed in battles with soldiers.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4FKR-6R00-015G-W4WC-00000-00<published>2005-03-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 6</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>DOOM & GLOOM</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WINTER BLAZE KILLS FIREFIGHTERS</p><p nitf:lede="true">A RARE winter forest fire killed four Portuguese firefighters today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The four, from the Coimbra fire brigade, were among a group of five battling a blaze in mountains near Mortagua, about 210km north-east of Lisbon, Coimbra mayor Carlos Encarnacao said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"There was a shift in the wind and they were overwhelmed by flames. One was able to get away, but four were caught in the fire," he said.</p><p>GORGE PLUNGE CLAIMS 15</p><p>AT LEAST 15 people, including five women, were killed and seven injured yesterday when a vehicle they were travelling in fell into a gorge in the northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh.</p><p>It is believed the driver lost control of the bus in the Kinnaur district.</p><p>HAITI POLICE SHOOT PROTESTERS</p><p>HAITIAN police fired at hundreds of protesters today, marking the ousting of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide one year ago, killing at least two people.</p><p>Protesters charged a police roadblock in Bel Air, a hotspot slum filled with Aristide militants and police responded first with tear gas and then bullets.</p><p>LUCK RUNS OUT FOR EX-POLICEMAN</p><p>AN ALBANIAN former police chief-turned-socialite businessman was blown up in the lift of his building early today by a remote-control bomb, four months after escaping a drive-by shooting.</p><p>Police said Vajdin Lame, 37, and a friend died when explosives placed on the roof of the lift taking them to Lame's eighth-floor luxury apartment blew up halfway. Police would not speculate on a motive for the killings.</p><p>BOMB INJURES AFGHAN COPS</p><p>A HOMEMADE bomb left three policemen fighting for life after it exploded under their vehicle today in the southern Afghan province of Helmand.</p><p>A committee has been set up to investigate the cause of the explosion in Lashkargah, the capital of Helmand.</p><p>FIVE DROWN IN BAPTISM CEREMONY</p><p>FIVE people drowned when a participant in a South African baptism ceremony went into a trance, waded too far out to sea near Durban and others tried to rescue him.</p><p>The tragedy happened on Saturday night off Battery Beach where members of the new Corinthian Church at Jerusalem, a part of the Zionist movement, was holding a mass baptism. The drowned were two pairs of brothers and a priest.</p><p>GIRL KILLED TRAVELLING TO AIRPORT</p><p>A 13-YEAR-OLD Long Island girl was killed and eight relatives injured when their airport shuttle bus was hit by a utility headed in the wrong direction on a Texas highway yesterday.</p><p>Brianna Titcomb, of Huntington, was thrown out of the window when the van rolled over.</p><p>Brianna, her parents, John and Dawn, brother, Brett, and relatives were on their way to the Dallas-Fort Worth airport.</p><p>GUNMEN FIRE ON ISRAELIS</p><p>GUNMEN opened fire on an Israeli vehicle in the West Bank last night, seriously wounding two people.</p><p>The incident took place west of Jerusalem near the Jewish settlement of Shilat.</p><p>PSYCH TESTS FOR ACCUSED KILLER</p><p>THE accused murderer of Dutch film-maker Theo van Gogh is having psychiatric tests in an attempt to explain his state of his mind at the time of the alleged crime.</p><p>Mohammed Bouyeri, 26, has been charged with shooting and then stabbing van Gogh.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8B-H3J0-TXN5-R0SH-00000-00Saving homes worth a singed backside2001-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 2Saving homes worth a singed backsideLOCAL HEROES, Bushfires, a scarred landscapeDanielle Woolage. Source: Illawarra Mercury

When the Premier, Bob Carr, yesterday hailed Helensburgh resident Sam Blackwell, 62, a hero, the council worker was lost for words.

"Aww gawd," he said. "I don't know what to say. I don't think I am a hero, I just did what any neighbour would do."

Mr Blackwell, who lives on the corner of Laurina Avenue and Blackwell Street, refused to leave his home despite three attempts by police to evacuate him as a firestorm ripped through last week.

As thousands of Helensburgh residents fled, Mr Blackwell, along with former Rural Fire Service volunteer George Abrahams, stayed put.

"I wasn't going anywhere," Mr Blackwell said. "I told them the only way they would get me out was in a bodybag. I was in the Darkes Forest fire in 1968 so I have had a bit of experience with this sort of thing."

Their stance saved nine of the 11 homes in the street. The pair also released three trapped dogs from burning houses.

Armed with a garden hose, a water can backpack, red hard hat and torch, Mr Blackwell attacked spot fires on one side of the street, while Mr Abrahams used a garden hose to extinguish flames across the road.

Mr Abrahams, who was forced to take cover in his car as the fire engulfed the street, described it as a scene from Star Wars.

"All these embers were just flying towards me," he said. "I would be lying if I said I wasn't scared. But we proved that if you have your wits about you, you don't endanger your life and if you stay with your house you can save it."

Mr Carr, who cut short a holiday to China to visit areas devastated by the bushfires, lauded the efforts of Mr Blackwell and Mr Abrahams yesterday.

"You are one of the heroes of this episode," he told Mr Blackwell. Mr Carr was shocked by the trail of destruction left by the fire that destroyed 10 homes in Helensburgh.

"It is tragic to see all these lost homes and all that they represent in terms of a family's hopes, sacrifices and aspirations," he said. Despite the Premier's praise, both men rejected hero status.

"There is no such thing as a hero. We just do what we can to save our homes and our neighbours' homes," Mr Abrahams said.

Relatively uninjured, Mr Blackwell said he felt "a bit of a burning sensation on my backside when I was putting out my garbage. My handkerchief had caught alight in my back pocket and singed my bum." One of the dogs "got a bit of a singed behind too".

ILLUS: Full of praise for two locals who refused to leave ... Mr Carr and local MP Ian McManus inspect the rubble that was once 52 Laurina Avenue. Photo: Kirk Gilmour

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YMH0-TXN5-R39F-00000-00SUN HERALD GIVEAWAYS1989-06-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 108SUN HERALD GIVEAWAYS

UNLESS indicated, just include your giveaway selection on the back of an envelope and send to: The Sun-Herald Giveaways, GPO Box 7031, Sydney, 2001. Entries close Thursday, June 22.

WIN DOUBLE TICKETS TO THE HARRY SECOMBE CONCERT

HE'S talented, cuddly and sings up a storm. He barely needs an introduction, but we'll give you one. You can win one of 15 double passes to see Sir Harry Secombe perform all his greatest hits - and demonstrate that legendary Goon Show wit - at his only Sydney concert at the Opera House on Wednesday, July 5, courtesy of Crawford Goldstone Organisation.

WIN A LLOYD COLE ALBUM

Slip on (to the sound system) something slick and stylish. We're celebrating the album release of Lloyd Cole And The Commotions: 1984-1989. All your favourites are here in this retrospective of the band's hits from the early Perfect Skin right through to Everything But The Girl and a re-mixed version of Forest Fire. You can win one of 15 cassettes of the album, courtesy of Polygram Records.

WIN TICKETS TO THE PREMIERE OF POACHERS

FANCY a breathtaking look into the world of big business, money and computer "hackers"? The Sun-Herald is proud to announce the premiere of a new Australian play, Poachers, from the writers of Friday and Fair Exchange, and featuring Emma Gray (pictured). The season runs from June 22 to July 15 at the Rocks Theatre, George St North, The Rocks. You can win a double pass to the June 25 performance. Just ring 954 4241 tomorrow between 9.15 and 9.30am.

WIN TICKETS TO MACEDONIA EXHIBITION

GO Greek with the compliments of the Australian Museum and Belvoir Street Theatre. Sun-Herald readers can win one of 10 double passes to see Sydney's latest block-buster exhibition, Ancient Macedonia, which until July 23, displays more than 400 artefacts spanning 7,000 years to the time of Alexander the Great. You will also see next Saturday's matinee session of Greek Tragedy at the Belvoir Street Upstairs Theatre.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H3N0-TXN5-R02Y-00000-00Words of note2001-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:12ZLexisNexisSUPPLEMENTPg. 28Words of noteBooks CHRISTMAS GIFT GUIDE 2001Susan Wyndham

The book we all need to give and receive - not just for Christmas - is the Dalai Lama's An Open Heart: Practising Compassion in Everyday Life, a follow-up to his enormously popular Art of Happiness.

But decency doesn't always make the most memorable characters in history or fiction. Every Australian should read Peter Carey's imagined life of Ned Kelly, True History of the Kelly Gang, a year old but winner of the Booker Prize and out in a gorgeous new paperback edition. Pair the novel with The Jerilderie Letter by Ned himself.

Gould's Book of Fish by Richard Flanagan is another fictionalised life of a real blackguard and the year's lushest novel - printed in multi-coloured ink with fish swimming through it.

More proof that the past is a very good present comes in Geraldine Brooks's plague novel set in 1666, Year of Wonders. A dying village might not seem like Christmas fare but this is also a graceful story of love and courage.

Tim Winton's first novel in seven years, Dirt Music, chases love up the West Australian coast. Give it with the accompanying CD of roots and classical music compiled by Winton with Lucky Oceans.

Someone you know (not just single women) would be thrilled to have Bridget Jones's Diary by Helen Fielding gift-wrapped with the movie soundtrack (Picador, $21 and $25 respectively). Throw in the sequel, Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason ($21).

Offer more light relief in a serious year with Red Dog by Louis de Bernières, a whimsical tale of a West Australian kelpie, for anyone 12 or older.

Ignore the critics. Salman Rushdie's Fury gives a chilling snapshot of Manhattan pre-September 11.

While we wait for an entirely new book from Helen Garner, her collected journalism in The Feel of Steel is as precise and emotional as her novels.

Also for non-fiction devotees: Gallipoli by Les Carlyon (Macmillan, $35), The Best Ever Sports Writing edited by David Headon (Black Inc, $49.95) and Fire by Sebastian Junger, in which the author of The Perfect Storm turns his dramatic powers to forest fire, war and terrorism (4th Estate, $27.95).

Good Reading magazine will help booklovers find their way through next year's forest of books.

FIVE ILLUS: 1. Good Reading magazine (monthly), $74 for a 12-month subscription, 9810 2477 2. Gould's Book of Fish, $50, Picador, Fury, $49.90, Jonathan Cape, An Open Heart, $24.95, Hodder 3. True History of the Kelly Gang, $18.95, University of Queensland Press, The Jerilderie Letter, $16.95, Text Publishing, Red Dog, $27.95, Knopf, The Feel of Steel, $21, Picador 4. Dirt Music, $45, and CD of related music, $31.95, ABC Shops 5. Year of Wonders, $27.95, 4th Estate; carved wooden antique bookends, $180, Michael A. Greene Antiques, 9328 1712
